reviewText:
The best simulation game ever!
I played this game before it came on Steam, and I really love it!
So I tought I should make a review because people need to know the hard truth about this game.

First of all, let's take a look at the graphics..
The game looks like some kind of a cartoon, which makes it really cool.
I shouldn't have done it in any other way, it just made so unique.

Than we got the possibilities.
This game has an enormous amount of modifications you can add to your game, by easily dragging into a folder..
With the mods your game get so much more intresting to play, with a million possibilities.
Even without modifications the game is still amazing to play, with many things to discover.
There is even a multiplayer modification which, of course, makes it posible to play together with friends, or just random people, and it's soo cool!

The developers of the game are amazing too, they listen to their players and add suggestions to the game.
Or sometimes add stuff to the game that has been inspired by amazing modifications.

You can easily play this game the whole day without noticing the time flying, every time your ship crashes you are challenged to make a ship that actually can fly to the moon, and if it doesn't work you try again, and again and you guessed it AGAIN!
Some people maybe think this is annoying but I think it's a good side of the game, instead of beating the game easily, you are challenged every time, in this way to get more into the game and learn more and more about real life space missions.

You even got different things to do, you can do training missions or other kind of missions.
You can start a carreer, play in sandbox-mode or even play in science mode, which makes it possible to both do research on planets for science points, and make ships using all the parts u want without unlocking them.

You can go to soo many different planets, which are made so cool.
They all got things like drag and stuff based on real planets, however some are changed a bit because it's still a game.
For example, taking of at Kerbin - Earth requires you to have a ship with quite some power, while taking off at the Moon is much easier because of the gravity.

There probably are some bad sides of the game, but I actually didn't discover those yet.
However if you are using modifications they may sometimes don't work quite well together and sometimes make your game suddenly crash. - But this isn't the fault of the developers so don't blame them.

If you want to see someone else's perspective of the game you should check out some other reviews, but my advice is to really buy this game if you like the things you see.
I would also recommend to watch some gameplays on YouTube, and maybe if you want you should search the internet for Kerbal Space Program Mods to see what kind of modifications you could add to your game when you bought it.

I will definitly keep playing this game for a long time and if I needed to give this game a mark, it would absolutly get a 10/10!

reviewText:
As an engineer who was quite into astronomy as a kid, I LOVE this game, and it probably couldn't have been any other way. I mean : it is about ACTUAL space travel, how awesome is that?

I'll recommend it, but there is one thing I can not stress enough : IT IS NOT FOR EVERYBODY.

There are basically two ways to play that game : either you build crazy rockets in sandbox mode and you see if your random construction somehow achieves orbit OR you actually try to become a good (in-game) rocket scientist and launch a planned payload to a specific destination in the solar system.

And to become such a rocket scientist  you will either need :
College level math and physics, as well as a huge excel spreadsheet
To read and follow tutorials, and have a huge patience with trial and error
And... that's not exactly the conception of fun" or a "game" to many people.

Just to give an idea of why you need the "school stuff" : this game expects you to know what newtons are. (And no
date: those are not clones of a guy who took an apple on the head XD) It expects you to count speeds in m/s rather than km/h (just as a scientist does). You must also understand the concept of relative vector speed in a 3D environment... and many other things.\n\nThe game features tutorials fortunately
recommended: but they only give the basics and you'll still have to learn most of the game by yourself.\n\nAnd even though the game simplifies a few aspects from reality (like for instance oxygen and astronaut's mental state management)
hoursPlayed: on what it actually simulates it is ruthless : no fuel left after a 3 hour mission (for you

votesFunny:

True.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm going to keep this somewhat short and sweet

At the time of writing, Kerbal space program is in beta and there is talk of how soon it will be until it emerges from beta. But since its release in July 2011, it grown to become an outstanding example of Enthusiasm, Humor, and Profound triamph in a game. No matter whether your accomplishing great feats of exploration and scientific achievement......Or maybe you watched your beloved ship erupt into flames and debris becuase of a fatally unseen flaw. There is always something spectacular to be seen (Like your blown-up ship) or something to have a laugh at (Again like your blown-up ship)

My recommendation?

Buy this game, do something great, do something ridiculous, mod it, find something else just as great and just as crazy to do. My little tip is that i get emotionally attatched to some of my kerbals (Especially Jebediah). There's so much fun to be had and tenderness to experience. There's no reason not to buy this game and experience it. So do it!!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A bit about the game and developers.
Kerbal Space Program is a space travel simulation game developed and published by Squad. Kerbal Space Program is their only game for now, and even that one isn't out yet. All of the review and game footage that you will see in this review is from ALPHA! Things could change when ever Squad feels they want something new.

About Gameplay.
As I said earlier, Kerbal Space Program is a simulation game. In it your objective is to build up a space craft and fly it into the space. You have a lot of different parts to chose from, with which you can create your space craft very unique! And It's very simple as well. All you need to do is Drag and Drop the part where you want it to be, and woala, you've got yourself a small aircraft. Of course, you do need to think about the laws of physics, and It will take you a couple of tries to even manage and get into the space! You need to think about how many engines should you take, how much fuel, how big should your ship be... And if it's too big, you should put it into couple of smaller pieces and just launch them into the space one by one.

That sounds very simple, doesn't it? Well I'm sorry to brake this down for you.. This game is insanely hard! Just imagine, you need to set up the space craft just perfectly! Then you need to set up the valid commands (what engines start first, then which ones fall to the ground while the new ones start, and so on and on), then you need to think about the gravity. You need to make your space craft go straight forward into the air until it reaches about 10 000 km. After that you should turn around 45 Degrees. By that time, you're almost out of the gravity's reach. But that is not all of it! Once you get your space craft out into the orbit, you will probably lose all of your fuel. So then you need to launch more fuel from the ground. Simple, right? Nope! By the time you get into the orbit, your other part of the space craft is already orbiting around the Earth" (i forgot the name of the in game planet

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One of, if not THE best early access games on the market.

The updates are fairly frequent and always add something new and exciting.

The devs are always willing to listen to the community to and will often hire popular modders to work on the game officialy, incorporating the mod into the game itself (with some changes for uniformity and game balance).

The game itself is excellent, and although it can be challenging to beginners, that's mstly due to the accuracy that space is portrayed in this game. It almos perfectly emulates zero-G environments and orbital mechanics. Despite this , once you understand the basics, the game is simple enough to reward experimentation, yet challenging enough to require it.

I cannot recommend this game highly enough.

At time of writing, verion 0.9.0 has just dropped, oficially bringing the game into beta.

reviewText:
I have much more hours in this game, I bought it before it was even on Steam.

Kerbal Space Program is a space-agency simulator where you control the agency itself and the actual Kerbonauts (astronauts). There are three gamemodes, career (you manage the actual agency with funds, popularity/approva, and research tech), science (same as before but just research) and sandbox with no limitations but there's almost no agency mechanics. Although because of that sandbox may sound like a lesser mode, the agency mechanics are really secondary.

The main gameplay is being the actual Kerbonauts and performing the mission, which you yourself can determine or you can take a contract. However building the rocket (or spaceplane) is just as important as actually flying it. There's a whole solar-system for you to explore, complete with asteroids and moons for some of the planets. Some of the planets even have irrational orbits, and some of those have moons with an irrational orbit to the planet. The game is realistic enough to be somewhat educational but loose enough to be a very fun game.

The game is somewhat difficult due to the loose-realism, but that is a good thing for myself. I'd rather a game be too hard (this game definitely isn't) than be too easy. Everytime I start a new save, I learn something new along the way everytime. Whether it's a more efficient way to get into orbit, faster way to dock, or even a way to use less parts for a rocket. I always learn something new, and I love that.

Also, KSP is one of the few games ever to exit early-access and actually be complete with no major bugs. That's dedication.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So let me say right off the bat, this game will not be for everyone, But you more than likely know before you read this review if the game is even close to up your alley.  In career mode, It takes a patience, common sense. There is alot of trial and error. I had seen alot of the reviews and decided that I was going to not visit any guides or wikis, Which made the game much more gratifying knowing I figured it out on my own.  After nearly 100 hours into the game, im getting ready to restart career and impose a hardcore mode on myself.  As stated on the main page of the game, this is early access, therefore still alot missing from the game, you almost have to make your own fun out of it ATM.  But even with features still missing, the game is alot of fun, I always consider a game worth the money if I get a dollar a hour out of it, this game far surpasses that, even off sale.

The physics of the game are very solid and very unforgiving, just like it should be. The amount of stuff  you can do is only limited by your imagination.  From orbiting a planet, to a complete Space Station around the games version of Mars.

I must say too that I am a bit worried that the updates have been so slow to come out, I got the game a few days before the asteroid missions and the sale (doh).  Come to find out that was the first update in something like 3 months.  That being said, I have also seen in rviews that the modding community is awesome, so that may make up for the lack of updates in a small way.  Becuase of my self imposed blackout on anything that could be a spoiler, i have not looked into the mods myself.  But after I get tired of my hardcore mode, thats my next stop.

Any questions, feel free to ask in the comments section.

Edit: I finally had to look up how to transfer fuel.  Spent 3 hours clicking on a docked craft trying to figure it out. :/

THIS GAME IS:
10% LUCK
20% SKILL
15% CONCENTRATED POWER OF WILL
5% PLEASURE
50% PAIN

AND 100% REASON TO DOWNLOAD THE GAME!"

I saw this on another review of another game

reviewText:
While writing this I have almost reached my 700th hour and that does not even include the ones I played offline, so I'm probably more near the 800th hour. Nevertheless, this is one of the greatest games I've ever played. It's difficult, yes. But not as difficult as it sounds or appears first. Watch Scott Manley's tutorials on youtube and with a little practice and patience you will be able to do all the cool stuff you can imagine. I don't want to misslead you, it can be a rly hard and even a little frustrating during the first couple of hours, but it's also so damn rewarding once you got past that initial learning courve.
So what does this game offer? A huge sandbox experience with lots and lots of content that has been build up and polished for about 4 years! You want to build a rocket? a (space)plane? a shuttle? a station? a moon (mun) lander? or a probe that travels across the whole system to reach the gas giant far out? Than do that! No one is stopping you! Your imagination is the limit, as much of a cliche that might sound like. But it's true and if you don't believe me, watch showcases of people on youtube. There is everything from Star War's podracers to real life replica missions.
And if you fail a couple of times, there is nothing bad about it. The game manages to make failures fun. How? Cause you see stuff spinning, crashing and exploding in ways you couldn't even imagine. This is the unique experience of KSP that I've been enjoying with the greatest community I've ever seen. If you have a question, than simply post it on the forum. There are so many experienced vets out there that help each other and especially the new people with theire knowledge and skill. It's a rly unique group of people that has kept the forum alive ever since the buggy first steps.
You might ask yourself where the hell you might take the inspiration from to build new stuff after 100th of hours. The answer is simple. KSP is easy enough to be fun once you get used to the basics, while still being acurate enough to build real life replicas from the Apollo and Space Shuttle Aeras to modern missions and designs like SpaceX's reusable boosters or Virgin Galactic's space ship one. It's all within the possibilities of this sandbox.
And if you want something more SciFi orientated? Then get a mod like interstellar or near future and you will get everything and more right at hand. Even for the type of player that enjoys a harder and more realistic simulation type of game there are easy ways to adapt the game to be just that. The moding community of this game is just huge. There is everything from physics driven algorithms that simulate hypersonic reentrie effects to adding whole new planets and solar systems. There is just so much content out there that you will literally never be able to see or play it all.

Long story short, after playing this game for years I sudenly felt a need, driven by nostalgia, to write this down and promote the best investment I ever did when it comes to a game.

I hope you will enjoy it as much as I did and still do! Cheers

reviewText: I started playing this game during the Beta and it quickly became the greatest game I've ever played and still is. I've played 600+ hours and I've hardly scratched everything you can do in this game. I can easily say, without exaggeration,  I'll be putting another 1000 hours if not more into this game. Games these days seem to go onto the market at 60$-120$, if you include all the DLC or pre-release shannanigans, for about 4-5 hours of enjoyable gameplay, 20 hours if your lucky. With Kerbal Space Program they're not even charging 50$ with a guarantee of continued FREE updates. I can not express enough the level of enjoyment anyone with any amount of interest in space exploration will get from this game. If your like me you'll get hooked on this game and before you realize it you'll have put in 100 hours of gameplay and be working towards setting up mining operations on any number of distant worlds, complete with orbiting space stations and/or colonies. Did I mention you can capture and/redirect asteroids then do whatever you want with them? Yes, that does include mining and/or building bases on them. What you do in this game is only limited to what you can imagine and build to get the job done...... unless you run your agency into the ground first of course.\n\nBEWARE THE KRAKEN!!

reviewText:
Kerbal Space Program. If I could sleep with a video game, this would be it. KSP is beautiful in almost every way! I can blow up my Kerbals on the launch pad and try and build a boat out of struts (I can't), or if I want to I can land on alien worlds and watch alien moons rise.

It runs on my Mac, making it a game that can run on anything short of a rotary phone. Really, any game that can run with an i3 processor and is this GOOD then should be a yes in everyone's book :D

The real fun comes when things go wrong. If it seems to go right first try, it won't. I think the best moment have come in failure. Once I killed Bill, Bob and Gwent Kerman after landing to rescue another Kerbal on a far-away moon before realising I was on the wrong side of the moon. While attempting to get back into orbit, I lost my velocity and plummeted into a xeno-ocean. Xeno - sea? Xenocean? I don't know .-.

In addition, this game has no cons. The stock game has plenty or shortcomings, but the modding community is the most diverse community in existence for a game on Steam...
You want clouds? There's a mod for that.
You want to eject you Kerbals and watch them parachute to safety? There's a mod for that.
You want to fly them up in an AI-flown spaceplane then shoot an AMRAAM missile at them from a ground base, then watch them jump out just in time before landing perfectly on top of the mountains? There's a mod for that. Well, actually about 12.

Don't bother with that astrophysics degree, play KSP. If you are considering buying this game, then HELL TO THE YES!
Like 124 / 10

reviewText:
From the papers of Wojak Feel 2/26/1962:

I have enjoyed every second of the 220 hours that I have played of this game. I have built over 2000 spaceships for the Kerbals so that they can get to the various planets in their solar system. It is a process of trial and error in building these spaceships since they tend to fall apart quite easily and when they do it has catastrophic results for the Kerbals manning them. I have conducted inventory this past Tuesday and I can report that as of this past week 26,000 Kerbals have lost their lives in service to their planet. The families of these Kerbals receive my deepest condolences and I am putting forth a motion with the Interplanetary League of Kerbal Nations (ILKN) to aid in providing financial reimbursement to help with funeral expenses and life insurance claims. In watching these brave Kerbals and Gerbals lose their lives I have inadvertently discovered a new passion. Killing Kerbals is to date the most exhilarating thing I have ever done. I thoroughly enjoy watching the life slip out of the eyes of these Kerbals as they are crushed under structural beams after the collapse of a separator ring or as they suffocate after the cabin is flooded with carbon monoxide due to an engine malfunction. I am therefore issuing a call to arms to the rest of the galaxy. This vermin has lived under us for long enough. I will petition the various solar systems to supply me with the necessary forces to complete my mission of mass genocide. I see the future as a joyous one where, having crushed the Kerbals, the various nations of this great galaxy of ours can rise above the shattered remains of the Kerbal Empire and join hands as a beautifully diverse master race. This is the promise I make to you my listeners: I will thoroughly destroy the Kerbals and everything they hold dear. I will be the scourge of the Kerbal Empire and will not rest until every last insignificant spec of Kerbal scum burns and I can take my place as king of the ashes. I swear by the staff of Jehovah that by the time I die, I will have destroyed every last trace of the Kerbal Empire and its commonwealth. I will meet every Kerbal I find without mercy or remorse. I will expend every resource I have to wipe the Kerbals off the face of every planet that they inhabit. No matter where they run, no matter what loyalist swine that they cower behind, I will seek out and destroy them with brutal efficiency. There will be no leniency, no forgiveness, no chance for appeal. The empire and its corrupt senators will be a stain on the face of history and even after their obliteration I will work tirelessly to make sure that this stain is thoroughly bleached out. I am also announcing the re-militarization of the Koprulu sector once the arms embargo is lifted. The annexed Kerbal colony on Duna will be used as a base of operations for this re-militarization and I am currently in negotiations with the Aldemari Republic to supply several Minotaur-Class fleets for the rebel navy including battle cruisers, frigates, and capitol ships. We have hired many privateering firms including the famous Black Sun crime syndicate to undertake raids on the Kerbals' trade routes. These privateers should not be needed for long however, as I have issued a galaxy wide decree that whoever does not cease all trade with the Kerbals by star-date 66155.3 will suffer the full extent of my power. In order to destroy the Kerbals we must also neutralize the solar systems allied with them. The Kerbal allied systems as well as their hired mercenary groups are as follows: Kairon, Flaxo, Kelnar, Ara Aquarii, Aquila Icarus, Calesius prime, Zodiac-355, Oculus cloud, Xm-934, and BBA 19J. I will give each of these systems a chance to pledge allegiance to the rebel cause before they are utterly destroyed. In order to disarm the vast Kerbal military I have issued arrest warrants for over 3000 Kerbal army officers. Further I am offering a reward of 600,000 xaljats to anyone who manages to apprehend the band of outlaws known as the Kerman Brothers. I will see Commander Jebediah Kerman of the 35th Kerbal regiment brought to justice for his crimes against the United Galactic Federation and will use the planet destroying laser currently in development to obliterate his home world of Kerbin prime while he watches. I can assure you that he will not be able to talk his way out of this punishment like he has so many times before. He will be helpless to save his planet just like I was helpless to save mine. In conclusion, I will impart with you the famous last words of Admiral Jorney Kerman before I flayed him alive at the Battle of Kelnard's pass: I really wish I wasn't here right now. Uh oh now my skin is gone."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Kerbal Space Program not only slices and dices, but it shakes the conventions of gaming up with this glorious take on running your own space program. Houston, we don't have any problems here because with Kerbal Space Program the imagination runs wild like Hulk Hogan in 1991. Make no mistake that if you do purchase this game you may have life changing experiences that include, but are not limited to: creativity, frequent trips to imagination land, and thoughts of becoming an astronaut yourself. If these conditions last for more than 4 hours please consult Kerbal Space Program.*

*This game should be supported by people who enjoy space, sandboxes, and early access games that are actually pretty well done in their current state.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Release Update: still great!
everything i said during early access still applies, and this game is definitely still worth getting.
Highly Recommended! also if you played during early access its worth checking out again. lots of new features, including completely revamped aerodynamics and heating physics made me start over again from scratch, and im loving every minute of it. blown up quite a few rockets learning the improved physics, and poor jebediah burned up in re-entry after losing control and facing the heat sheild the wrong way :'( , but ive learned a thing or 2 along the way and recently got my first ship into stable orbit and back safely. its also worth mentioning that the new aerodynamics physics allows for vastly improved space plane gameplay. i actually built, flew, and safely landed my first plane before getting my first rocket into stable orbit, and with way fewer attempts; something i struggled with, even in sandbox mode with everything unlocked, during the beta.
also the con i mentioned in beta is still there but is easily fixable with mods :)

Early Access Review:
ive had some bad experiences with early access games and told myself never again. my freinds however convinced me otherwise and im glad they did. this game is just about to enter beta, but it feels like a pretty solid game already. the gamemodes feel complete and the engine feels solid. ive had a tremendous amount of fun and have yet to explore all it has to offer.  im currently in the process of trying to build a space station for refueling so my ships dont have to carry all the fuel for their entire mission from launch. im also trying to get my team thats on the mun" home with all their science data intact (my design didnt include enough fuel to get them all the way back from the mun)
date: so now im setting up a retreival mission. the game is merciless
hoursPlayed: and i actually consider this one of its strengths. you learn something with every attempted mission. also

95/100

Nice job Squad, great devs, just make it run smoother and smoother in future updates!!!

reviewText:
Build. Fly Dream.

One of the best sandbox games in this decade of sandbox games. You are given a whole star system open to exploration; Mun, Duna, Laythe, all these planets are yours, except Eve, attempt no landing there. However each trip has new challenges and the game does not hold your hand through them you will run out of fuel, burn up in re-entry, and explode and explode and explode. That rush you feel though when you finally plant that flag and safely return to Kerbin is incomparable.

This is the gateway drug to space. Nasa, Esa, and Roscosmos should pay squad for recruiting their next generation of scientists, engineers, and pilots.

reviewText:
Kerbal Space Program was the first Early Access game I ever bothered to try and it turned out to have been a great decision; KSP has evovled into a stunningly fun and creative game that packs not only surprisingly well-done physics together and perfectly decent graphics with infinite replayability and different game modes but also a small dose of witty comedy.

I think an important thing to realize with KSP is that, yes, Kerbals that live on planet Kerbin (essentially the astronauts that you get to have inside the space crafts you build) do have a ‘minionesque’ comical look but in no actual way does this really ever affect the simulation aspect of the game - it still packs in a pretty hardcore simulator with the actual ship resources like fuel, electricity and mono propellant having to be carefully managed during advanced missions. Successfully piloting a craft and docking with a space station is seriously no joke. Flight dynamics are also very realistic with you actually having to have at least a rudimentary understanding of how a rocket or airplane works in order to have one you designed actually ever get off the ground.

All in all this provides a game that has you spending hours designing a ship straight out of your imagination using a very wide variety of parts in order to accomplish any mission you could think of like launching from Kerbin, landing on the Mun (moon) and then returning those happy little guys back home. All of this happens while constantly having chuckles at the witty ship part descriptions while in Build Mode or the quirkiness of the Kerbins that you're having go on EVA's outside your space station.

Mod support is huge and makes the game essentially extendable to anything you could possibly ever want from a space sim.

If you like space sims you will like this, trust me.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What a truely amazing game!

I HIGHLY recommend this game to anyone even remotely interested in space like gaming.

The core game is really great - but the modding community, and available mods for this game, adds value to this game unlike anything I've ever exerienced.

This game has 3 modes (sandbox, science, and career), each having it's own unique experience. After spending a little bit watching some of Scott Manley's videos on youtube, you'll be well on your way to creating your very own space program. You can literally design every detailed aspect of your spacecraft, accomplish things in space, and have endless hours of fun. Iliterally can't stop playing this game...seriously!

If you're wondering whether or not this is for you, go check out Scott Manley's videos on youtube, and get a taste of this masterpiece that is KSP.

It's not rocket science...well okay, actually it is. But after spending a little time on those vids, you'll be well on your way.

reviewText:
Why are you still not playing it?

This game is as pivotal to sandbox games as was minecraft , but in a completely different department - depth.

Simulated solar system, chance to experience and learn real (almost - still cut some corners - no la-grande points, orbits are mostly radial without additional simulation after a swing, but none the less) rocket science.
Sense of achievement with this game is as huge as in dwarf fortress, when through error, misery, failure, countless tries you finally get your ♥♥♥ to <s>mars</s> Duna. And it only goes up from there.

And then there are mods. My. GOD. Modding scene for this game gone above and beyond:
You want attachment systems? Sure.
You want to mine? Since 1.0 - embedded, but there are also kethane and open resource system.
You want to build rockets on distant planets - sure - Extraplanetary launchpads got you covered.
You want even more? How about warp drive and additional systems mod?
Want more realism? TAS Mods got you covered with food, water and waste resources.
Want working actuators? Infernal robotics got you covered.

I got more than 600 hours of gameplay out of this game (300+ on steam, 300 prior) and it still has a little bit more to offer, and with newer mods coming around - it is always fun to occasionally get back to it.
This game is like a good song or a good movie - memorable, can be watched/listened a dozen times and never gets old.

So, once again, why are you still not playing it?

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nImagine, if you will, any alien race on another planet.  Image them looking up at the stars and trying to reach them.  We went through our own space program in the 60s, and we got a taste of what it means to leave your own gravity well.  Well, certainly we can't be the only species trying to do this.  Playing Kerbal Space Program makes me feel connected to every other species attempting to leave their home planet.  It's not just us on Earth, but everywhere.  KSP makes me feel like I have NASA in my backyard and can throw together a rocket and try it out whenever I like.  I recommend this game for young and old alike.  If you like rockets because they're cool or because you remember Neil saying those memorable words, please play this game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There is simply no shortage of places to go and things to do.

Once, I put a pirate ship into orbit.  A pirate ship.  In orbit.  Hell yeah, it had cannons!  It could sail the stars as Odysseus sailed the seas, but curiously enough couldn't float upon landing in an ocean.  In this way, I discovered the need for testing.

Another time, I built a large, mobile glove-shaped buggy out of airbags that was designed to safely catch spacecraft that were landing at significant multiples of the speed of sound.  Sifting through the wreckage of that first test revealed serious flaws, but that's just the sort of can't-do negativism that further engineering tweaks can and will overcome as you play KSP.  Soon, the crack engineering team realized they could save millions by just installing an airbag or two on any landing vessel itself.  En garde, gravity!

Another time, I dropped a jeep on the Mun that landed on its side doors, trapping the Kerbals inside.  My OnStar insurance coverage did not extend beyond the atmosphere, so I launched a rescue mission to flip the Munar jeep.  Then, I toured the Munar craters in a jeep.  The rescue team had no way to return home and no other plans, so they hopped in for the ride.  Yeah, riding dirty in Kerbal Space Program.

300+ hours in, and I've only begun building space stations.  I've only landed on a handful of planets and moons.  The call for exploration lures me ever upward, even though in my first ever rocket launch, I didn't know better than to not walk out the capsule door mid-flight.  As I fell back to the surface, my body aglow in the flames of reentry, a thought crossed my mind: maybe I should develop a large, mobile catcher's mitt for situations such as these.

KSP is a game in which you decide where to go, what to do, what to make, and how many boosters you need to accomplish all of these things--much research has been done on this very subject before you arrived, and the data has always pointed toward moar."

KSP is challenging to learn--truly challenging.  It is also so

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nKerbal Space Program offers an immense amount of tinkering away at spacecraft that fail and fly.  Spending a few minutes slapping something together that barely gets off the ground can give some satisfying laughs. But when you've spent a good bit of time perfecting a craft and getting to the many milestones (getting airborne, breaking atmosphere, maintaining orbit, landing on The Mun) you'll have so much pride in yourself for accomplishing something that you'll feel like a rocket scientist.  The physics at play in KSP can allow a previously failed launch to have a chance of succeeding next time so taking several attempts is rewarded (don't give up).  Trial and error is what drives this game and if you love the idea of ironing out the wrinkles in your design and watching it pay off, then you won't be disappointed at all in KSP.  Let your creativity and problem solving skills run wild!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Rocket Science! Explosions! Fun!

Kerbal Space Program (KSP) puts you in charge of a space agency (think NASA) whose goals are... actually that's pretty much up to you. The game's career mode will give you missions you can accept, such as get a rocket into orbit" or "land on the Mun (Moon)
date:
and you get rewards for doing so such as research points to unlock more modules, prestige to do... stuff, and monies to pay for things. But really you can do whatever you please. And outside of career mode which structures your objectives and gameplay to an extent is a sandbox mode that lets you do as you please without worrying about unlocking things or having money for them.

The game basically has two main aspects (three if you include the Career Mode stuff described above): building stuff to send into space, and then launching that stuff and making it do other stuff. Designing successful rockets (and later on spaceplanes) can be a bit difficult, since you have to worry about stuff like the weight, the power of the engines, maneuverability, and more. The 1.0 Update plans to add a tool that will let you see potential problems with your designs before you actually try them out, but until then you basically just have to wing it and hope that your designs don't crash or explode in a spectacular manner.

Once you have your designed rockets (or spaceplanes), then you get to launch them and perform whatever mission" you have chosen for yourself. You have to fly the craft yourself
recommended: which often requires great precision and timing. Assuming you don't just crash and die horribly
hoursPlayed: your biggest concern is fuel
voteText: and running out of it at a bad moment can make you go back down towards the planet (you did attach a parachute
helpfulPercent: right?) or leave you drifting in space unable to return home unless you can find some way to rescue them.\n\nThis is not an easy game even on easy difficulty settings
votesHelpful: but it is one that can give a real feeling of accomplishment when you make successful designs
votesTotal: achieve your first orbit
votesFunny: make that fateful landing on the Mun
commentsCount: and much more. It gives you an appreciation for the difficulties that real world space agencies face when planning or performing such missions.\n\nAt the time of writing

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is:
- how to do edutainment
- a demonstration of the power of adding a little personality to an otherwise dry and difficult challenge, making failure hilarious instead, and success all that sweeter
- sufficiently gameified that you can get to the moon-analogue and back using a wobbly stack of exploding things, steering with WASD, and do it within a few hours rather than years of meticulous planning and precision engineering
- sufficiently accurate in the broad strokes that you can get a really good gut understanding of rocket science and orbital mechanics, and one of the most notable Lets Play-ers (Scott Manley) has a couple of physics and astronomy degrees
- absolutely thriving with mods to push it further into either direction if you so desire (and as a pure utility, Kerbal Alarm Clock is excellent for managing scaling up to multiple concurrent interplanetary missions)
- far, far more rewarding than a level up!" screen when you set yourself a dot in the sky to visit

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you are even slightly considering buying this game, then stop thinking and just do it. You will spend countless hours hurling Kerbals at the stars and hoping they'll stick.

One caveat though; the secret knowledge of prograde and retrograde, apoapsis and periapsis, radial and normal, is hard-won and not for the faint-hearted. You will fail, gloriously, many many times. You will rejoice over every successful burn, and agonise every time you send a hapless Kerbal spinning off into the infinite night.

Good luck, brave adventurer, and remember to add plenty of solar panels.

reviewText:
The best simulation game I've ever played! The stock game is amazing enough for trying to get to orbit, and other planets (very hard, still havent landed everywhere in one trip.. after 1000 hours). Also boats and land vehicles if you're into that (on other planets too why not?). But with mods... it can become every other sim game youve ever wanted! And a handy community run mod database and manager (CKAN) to make it easy!

Flight combat sim: install realistic aerodynamic mod and weapons mod to make your own F15s fight your own Su-27s (FAR and BDarmory).

Colony building: there are life support and resource collecting mods that challenge you to scan for the right site and use resources on any of the planets to sustain a colony of kerbals; even manufacture new parts there (MKS, TAC lifesupport, extraplanetary launchpads, scansat, remotetech).

Hardcore realistic simulation? Theres a mod that converts the stock star system to a 1:1 scale replica of the solar system, with real-life satellite data used (real solar system, realism overhaul, probably more mods - these are too scary for me). Realism overhaul I think uses historical rocket data so you can create saturn-V replicas with the accurate fuel mixtures and everything!

Or go the other way and get futuristic mods to create antimatter powered near-light speed craft to visit entire other solar systems (nearfuture, KSPinterstellar)!

And with the new 1.1 release on Unity 5, you may actually be able to use these mods without running out of memory!

Between the great modding community and active devs (for over 5 years!) this game will continue to get better and better, so even at full price of $40 its a great deal!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is highly addictive and quite hardcore space faring sim. I call it NASA sim with kerbals. Having been playing space trading games like Elite or X3 I have always dreamt of game that actually does have orbital navigation and things like that. But this game is really much more than that - You actually colonize the space with Your own custom built space stations, planetary landers, planetary bases, rovers and anything Your imagination can create. And the building bricks" are based on real world counterparts - no teleporters or stargates here.

Should this game have a story like Mass Effect and space trading economy like X3 series
date:
it would be my dream game come true.

I would highly recommend this game to everyone who dares to test his own creativity in building sophisticated craft that can actually fly and land on distant planets and moons.

And You will have to land there if You are playng campaing mode
recommended:
because that is a way You gather more science data for Your scientists and You will need that to learn better components for Your spacecrafts.

This game has also a huge modding comunity already that have created a lot of content that can extend a stock functionality.

There are also tons of tutorials on Youtube that will explain a game in detail and a dedicated wiki to learn more.

Try not to be distracted by appearances of those kerbals - they will share Your passion of flying high and far away and they will show their appreciation if You do things right! :)

Have fun and fly safe!"

Each update provided a TON of new stuff, slowly changing this game from a sandbox into a fully functional single player game (which still can be played in sandbox mode).\n\nI have over 240 hours playing this game and have still not achieved all thats accomplishable. This game is the ♥♥♥♥. Plain and simple. Squad, thank you for putting the time and effort into finishing this project and not walking away with everyone's money as so many early release developers have done. This is what early access is all about!

reviewText:
Kerbal Space Program is probably the best Early Access game out there. Yes, it's even better than DayZ. It's an amazing game, and I don't even purchase simulators. If I buy a game from a genre I don't like/care less about, then you know that I knew something was up with the game. I'm not much of a Early Access guy, but this game was quite an exception.

Graphics
The visuals, unfortunately, are pretty weak so far. The textures look like those from games where the textures are glitched and it's all blurry. The Kerbonauts are also not much better. However, the graphics look nice on occasion, so it's not bad everywhere. Not much to say about visuals in this game.

Gameplay
The gameplay is much like a simulator (which it is) where you build a ship and launch it, and with the proper ship, you can either get to the Mun and beyond, or crash and burn and possibly kill Jebediah Kerman. And if you DO kill Jeb, then I will find you and make sure that neck of yours makes a mighty fine snapping noise as you collapse to the ground. Anyway, the construction is solid and is easy to learn. Just be warned though, you will need to know the basics to physics if you want to make a decent ship. To add on to that, the pilot controls are also solid and makes the game more difficult in a good way. Why else do you think I enjoyed FTL, Super Meat Boy, Dark Souls, and all of the other throw-your-controller/keyboard-at-the-wall simulators? The only con to the gameplay is that the learning curve can be quite steep and requires lots of blood, sweat, and tears (Okay, that's a bit of an exaggeration) into the game. But, we'll get into replayability later.

Story
The story? Well, there is absolutely no story in this game whatsoever. No trace. There's a small amount of lore, but that's it. The story to this game will NOT be counted towards KSP's final score.

Audio
The audio is decent, but the noises keep looping and it sounds repetitive and it needs lots of work. However, I love the songs a lot, so that'll boost the score quite a bit for this game.

Replayability
The replayability is very, very, very, high. This is one of the few games on Steam that could easily take 1000 hours of your life, sitting on the throne alongside Team Fortress 2, Dota 2, Skyrim, and a few others. There is so much trial and error in the game that for you to actually get to the Mun, it would take you hours after hours after hours. Look at the other reviews' hours. I only have a small amount, but let's use common sense: Most of the reviews have over 1k hours logged into the game, so what does that mean? Does it have high or low replayability? That's what I thought. The reasons the game is highly replayable was explained in the Gameplay part of the review already.

Verdict
In the end, Kerbal Space Program is an impressive and difficult space simulator. Despite a few flaws, this game is well worth the price and is worth buying, Early Access or not. I highly recommend the game. Why waste your time dealing with connecting into servers and getting captured by bandits all the time in DayZ when you could build a bunch of ships and then watch them all burn to the ground after failing miserably and then decide that if Jeb dies, you need to restart the launch or else I WILL FIND YOU- I mean, you will get sad. Oops.

Graphics- 5/10
Gameplay- 8.5/10
Story- NONE
Audio- 6/10
Replayability- 10/10

.:7.7/10:.

+Monsterous amount of replayability
+Funny ways to watch your ships crash
+Solid piloting controls
+Simple-to-learn but hard-to-master construction
+Great songs

-Required experience at physics and other things to understand the game
-Mediocre visuals
-Small amounts of audio, loops sound boring

reviewText: This is far and away the most entertaining game I've ever played. Which is not to say that an FPS isn't more exciting or anything, but because of the stellar physics engine and the game's foundation in real-world orbital physics, I have never had my brain more taxed while learning to play a game. And because of that, when you finally do succeed in a Mun landing, or even your first Kerbin orbit, the amount of satisfaction is just insane. Because it's not *just* about better reflexes, or a stronger sense of strategy—You succeed in KSP based on *actual knowledge* gained during gameplay. (And many, many hours of tutorials and failure...)\n\nSo yeah. Get it. It'll satisfy all kinds of nerdery in the best way.
voteText: 11 of 12 people (92%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
First game on Steam I've been willing to take time to write a because I feel this game deserves it. Yes it's a long review, however again, this game deserves it.

GAME DESCRIPTION:
You own the Kerbal Space Program and your facility is equipped to launch various rockets off the launch pad or aircraft off a runway to send items in orbit, dock with orbiting stations, travel/survey/land on other planets, conduct science experiments, take samples and materials from planets/asteroids, build bases on other planets, or just explore. Campaign mode allows you to start with very basic rocketry equipment and buildings in which you can accept contracts that offers rewards of money and science you can use to purchase upgrades of buildings and research additional items to further your mission capabilities. In addition, you can hire new Kerbals to your crew that includes pilots, scientist, and engineers and advance their effectiveness with each successful mission. If you'd like to skip to the good stuff and jump right into the action, you can play in Sandbox mode which already has everything unlocked and nothing cost money. Sandbox mode also allows you to save your progress so you can always comeback and continue sending things up in space.

PROS:
+The unbelievably accurate physics and mechanics are always fun
+Near endless possibilities of various rockets, satellites, space stations you can build.
+Can send fueling ports, stations, satellites, or rockets in orbit and let them orbit in real-time while you build something else to dock, refuel, rendezvous with it, etc. You could do this 100s of times and have thousands of things orbiting whatever celestial body you chose.
+Can be played as a sandbox type game or campaign
+The solar system is insanely vast. If you were not not speed up time in travel, travel time is very accurate. 2 days to get to the moon and years to get to the outer planets (in near real-time). Thank God they included time warp lol!
+Extremely HARD at first = pure joy and satisfication when you accomplish what you're trying to acheive.
+Music is fun and fitting depending upon your location. Beautiful galatic music plays in space
+Beautiful space visuals. Although I'd recommend a few visual mods to enchance this
+Minimal bugs/glitches. I've had one crash of the game in 60 hours, however I believe it was my computer :). Otherwise, I haven't ran into any gamebreaking glitches.
+User interface for building the rocket is VERY user friendly and makes it downright fun to use your imagination to build something

CONS:
-I feel the tutorials are lacking. While there are some tutorials to help you get started and they're very helpful, There's nothing that really explains what most of the items to build your rocket do. Instead, most item descriptions are just funny little paragraphs that doesn't always explain the item's function. While I do like the comical approach and it seems fitting for the game, it should at least always say exactly what function the item serves and/or why you may need it. Or, there should be a tutorial on every item and it's use (like what batteries, docking ports, thermal reactors, decouplers, etc. do)
-While I did state in the pros there's endless possibilites of what you can build, I still feel almost all items available are still lacking in variety - such as engines, fuel tanks, lights, batteries, RCS pods, science, structural, and aerodynamics to name a few. Mods do ease this and offer many more to chose from, however I've found many mods to be graphically glitchy and some I've found that do work I felt should've been included stock in game.
-Campaign contract requirements are VERY aggravating at times. Sometimes they make no sense and feel out of place. For example, one contract has you test a specific rocket while submerged in water...really? So you have to launch, navigate over water, land safely in the water, and then boost your rockets while submerged - in which they do absolutely nothing other than just burn out...just weird, but ok (yes I realize some planets have water). Some people may like this, but I've found no use for contracts like these.
In addition to the above, I feel the contracts cause the campaign to way too slow and become frustrating due to them being tedious and many being repetive that require you to test the same item, but it just changes the requirements making it a pain in the ♥♥♥. For example, one rocket you may have to just test at 50,000km...easy enough. But then another contract will be offered to test the same item, but at 52,000km, not in orbit, and within 450-500m/s. So you may be at 52,000km but if you test it at 501m/s or 449m/s, you fail. Quite aggravating and again, this may not be a con for some, but I feel tests/contracts like these are a waste of time spending hours trying to get everything right, making the campaign move and feel VERY slow and near non-rewarding.

OVERALL:

That said, if you like space or anything space related, get this...period. I've played 75 hours and I've litterally scratched the surface of what you can do. I've managed to place items into orbit, build and dock stations, orbit satellites for research, and land and return from the moon. However, I still have yet to learn building rovers, advanced science stations, traveling to other planets, etc.  When I zoom out after I've traveled to the moon and look at the solar system, it's insane how large the solar system is. It makes it look like I've just merely accomplished stepping out on my front doorstep - even though the in-game and real-world travel time was days. This game offers thousands of hours of gameplay and I've not come remotely close to losing interest. It's no doubt the best (if not only) realistic space-mission simulator with nearly an endless amount of possibilities and customizations. It lets your imaginations run wild. However, that said, be warned it's a simulator that takes patience! If you lack patience, this is not for you. But if you have patience, when you finally accomplish what you want the feeling of satisfaction is like no other!

RATING: 8.5/10
-1.5 as I do feel the campaign could be a bit better if it offered better contracts making it easier to get into, some item choices lack variety (again, alleviated with mods), and item's descriptions, tutorials, and purpose of use is severely lacking

Edit: Thank you Kevin for pointing out the saving process. It's not described anywhere in game (that I could find), so thank you for that.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nKerbal Space Program is one of the best sandbox games I've played, even though it is currently in development. You are given unlimited possibilities in a number of settings, be it orbit, on the surface of your home planet Kerbin, or even on another heavenly body, such as the cleverly named Mün, or Duna, a Mars like planet.  On the sandbox aspect, you are given loads of different odds and ends to do as you please with, and the only limit is your imagination.  Things like replica space-planes, and huge space-stations await you in this new universe. Don't expect to be a pro right away though, as fifty-one hours into the game even I still have mishaps. The KSP community is incredibly supportive however, and there are great sources for help. If you get bored with what the developers give you, it is made incredibly easy to add plugins and part-packs to the game, with a website called the SpacePort. KSP is a great game for all ages, too, because unlike the theme nowadays of shoot-em-up and gore, you are challenged with expanding the frontiers of your own race of little green men.

KSP is like Dwarf Fortress but with less dwarven fortresses and more space!
It´s a game where you decide what you do.
You could build a space station, a base on the Mün, a VTOL to cruise on the planet Kerbin, a network of sattelites, some space fighters to destroy previously build stations or something completly different.

If you´re somewhat connected with the KSP community, you will learn tons of new terms like Kessler Syndrom, Hohmann transfer, apoapsis, periapsis, prograde, retrograde, aerobrake, gravity turn and many more!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Jebediah sits alone on the face of the Mun, gazing back into the blue sphere that is his home planet of Kerbin. Meanwhile on Kerbin, an enormous rescue ship is being driven to the platform, ready to shoot to the Mun and whisk Jebediah back. The countdown starts- 5... 4... 3... 2... 1... ignition. The thrusters fire up, and the rocket begins to grumble off the launchpad. Suddenly, one of the rockets explodes.  The main shaft collapses in a plume of fire, with shrapnel flying in every direction. Jebediah will have to wait another day.
Kerbal Space Program is a rocket building sandbox game, where you run a space program manned by little green Kerbals. While the game is a bit pricey for your averadge Steam game, I assure you, it's worth it. There is no more satisfying feeling than watching that lander that you meticulously designed and refined plant itself on the surface of another planet.

The Good:
-Practically endless replay value
-Frequent, good updates
-Excellent modding community
-Gameplay is rewarding and deep.
-The game is incredibly stable- even while designing huge rockets, I have yet to experience a single crash or lag spike.

The Bad:
-Graphics are decent on the ships, but the ground textures are so poor that it's often difficult to gauge your elevation.
-Space ships are illogically wobbly at times
-The user tutorial is not very good- it doesn't cover docking, interplanetary navegation, or even landing

reviewText:
Elon Musk Simulator
This is an example of Early Access done correctly and with the last patch (1.1.2) KSP finally
matured in a must have for space lovers.

This is a complex and deep game and by no means easy while at the same time it's super fun and doesn't feel like a chore to play even if you fail, and you will fail A LOT:
your rockets will explode and your Kerbals will be slaughtered in the crudest ways while you will be laughing like a maniac at your screen.

A little note of caution:

DON'T BE AFRAID TO MOD THE GAME!Everything the game lacks (tools, parts, mechanics) can be easily added trough mods and they will make your life easier in certain areas while making it absolutely nightmarish on other aspects due to the increased realism.

And trust me when I say that the Sky IS NOT the limit.

reviewerDisplayName: The Lord Fleet Admiral, KW MA
reviewText:
An amazing flight/space simulator, with amazing depth and detail, as well as vast scope. From building space-pleanes(and not-so-space planes), to hi-tech rockets to land on everything from the mun to Dres, as well as do orbital science, this game is a incredible space program simulator.
In addition, it is fully modable(and has a huge modding community with hundreds if not thousands of mods), and has cooperated with big-name groups like the ESA and NASA.
I highly recommend buying this, and i can only say, there is no such thing as to many struts, and check(and then RE-check) your stages. And then check them for a third time, just to be sure........

Easily, 11/10

Addendum:

With the update to 1.0, this game only gets better, They redid the atmospheric model, tweaked all the parts to be more realistic, and added tons of new parts to the game. And of course, if its something they didnt include, you can be sure some modder on Curse or the KSP forums made a mod for it. It is so expansive, i cant even go over all of it here. Check out Scott Manley's YouTube channel for in-depth learning on how to play, and just get right into it, it is well worth the buy, and the time.

20/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A must have for space/rocket fans!
KSP provides a large set of components and functionality with a relatively bug-free simulation of physics.
I've read reviews mentioning repetitive crashes or the lack of Steam Workshop integration, I personally had 2 KSP crashes in all my game time (77 hours) so that is fairly alright. The mod installation is as simple as putting the mod folder into your GameData folder, that's it.
Talking about mods, the mod support seems to be great. I've never looked into modding it myself, but since there are mods adding mineable ressources to planetoids or doing complete mapping scans from certain orbits there is a lot of room there :)

Who do I recommend this to?
Engineers": People that like to Trial&Error in games
date: that like taking challenges and eventually mastering them. In KSP
recommended: the difficulty of these challenges depends on you (i.e. sending two rockets with station segments into orbit or try it in one turn
hoursPlayed: which is more cost efficient etc etc)\n"Organizers": People that love doing stuff as calculating orbits (orbital period
voteText: "best suitable inclination" and so on)
helpfulPercent:
Thrust-To-Mass Ratios and all the tons of numbers you find in rocket science :P
"Pilots": People that have fun with coordinating a vessel in space near a fragile station to it's docking port ;)

Most of you will be all three of them
votesHelpful: but interestingly you can lay your focus on whichever you want.\nAlso the humor of the game is amazing
votesTotal:
so from my side:

A BIG YES to Kerbal Space Program!

(PS: If you decide to buy it now
votesFunny: check out Scott Manley's KSP tutorials. He's kind of the iconic figure of KSP tutorials and it will make your first hours a LOT more understandable)"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Kerbal Space Program managed to do something that many games are unable to do, they can make me come back to it after being forgotten in 6 months.

This game is ludicrously fun, it's got education in it aswell, you can fly rockets to the outer rim of the Kerbol System, Fly SSTOs to docking stations and then proceeding to land in the arctic, Drive rovers over mountains and make sucky boats unless you put Vac. Co. Air intakes on the under side of it, all of these things can be simple or ridiculously complicated (As in, you build a spaceplane, it looks awesome and when you put it on the runway, you start the engines only to find that the plane does the immelmann maneuver and crashes into the ground in a fireball as soon as it gain flight.)

There are also a lot of very well hidden easter eggs on other planets that are really hard to find without some videos giving you co-ordinates, one of the easier easter eggs is the monolith near the Space Center, it appears to be nothing more than a dot at a distance

You can succeed in this game and feel greatly achieved, with getting all them new modules with the science that you're going to get, or you can fail miserably and have a massive laugh with the 100 megatons worth of volatile kerosene going all over the place, destroying whole parts of the Space Center, until eventually a hell kraken comes and snatches you into space (This a bug that blacks out the screen and frazzles the altimeter)

Straight 10/10 for me and likely many others

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm one of those people who never bought a game, relying on piracy for almost 15 years. KSP changed that.
During more than one year of playing it and perhaps even 2000 hours of game time collected, I've never regret the spent money.

As this is a work in progress, it can't be fully evaluated, but judging by the current status, it has crossed the line of just having a potential to become big. It really became big.
Its Unity engine doesn't allow it to be very flexible for the developers because the bottleneck is Unity itself. Nevertheless, the game graphics is visually appealing.
This is one of the most stable WIP games ever. Crashes are very rare even if one tweaks the game using various plugins and mods.
It's educational, it's open to expanding by others and the community is fantastic. One of the most peaceful communities I've encountered online, probably due to the fact that such games aren't generally appealing to aggressive types of people.

There is still much work to be done, but I already see this as one of the games that will become important in the history of computer games.

reviewText:
There is something really cool about this game... But I have a terrible memory and can't quite remember it.

Could it be building your own piece of space debris, launching it with the hopes that it won't quite crash into the surface of the planet, and then setting your kerbal, who is likely quite dizzy or nauseated (maybe even lobotomized), into the surface of the planet and claiming said planet for the glory of SCIENCE!  No, that sounds pretty cheesy...

Maybe it was Building a space station piece by piece and then attempting to dock these seperate pieces at precise intervals, only to accidentally fly through the near complete station because you didn't un-accelerate time fast enough to slow down (so much is wrong with that).  No that sounds frustrating...

Oh Oh, I know... It is undoubtedly creating a series of unmanned orbiting vehicles that all orbit in such a manner that they would allow instantaneous communication across the star system of Kerbin if there was any need for such a thing when you are but one of a handful of signs of habitation on your home planet let alone the Kerbin System.   No that sounds tedious...

Oh yes, that is it... it is using your ineptitude at physics to break the physics engine attempting to create all of your science fiction romanticisms like the Death Star, a space boat, a Gundam, Star Destroyer, a Halo Station (or ringworld as I would prefer), any number of space vehicles in science fiction, as well as inaccurate replicas and jury rigged models of today's human cosmonaut program.

Well whatever you enjoy, be it making a series of ICBMs and attempt to destroy your own base, or create complex rocketry designs to reach the distant planets, or even capture an asteroid and give Kerbin ANOTHER moon, or even giving Mun a moon (moon-ception)  You can do just about anything you can imagine in KSP.  Except the things you can do in game like COD or GTA, well, except kill people, but hey accidents happen.  Especially when you strap several hundred tons of rockets and fuel on haphazardly in an attempt to get into orbit.

So yeah KSP, flight sim, orbit sim, crash sim, not an explosion sim, non-newtonian physics sim, or underwater exploration sim...  I mean, just get this game... its not rocket science... well it doesn't have to be.

reviewText:
My favorite game. There's so much to do, and so many places to go. A whole  world  solar system of freedom and opportunity awaits!

You can play in sandbox, science mode, or career mode. In sandbox mode, you have unlimited funds, and everything is unlocked. In science mode, you have infinite funds, but you need to unlock things with science. In career mode, you have limited funds and science, as well as reputation. You must accept contracts from companies to fund your space program, and progress through the tech tree.

The game has in-depth tutorials and a guide, as well as different scenarios to try out. The community around the game is great, and Squad (the company that makes KSP) is great. I have seen them implement many things the community asks for, and even bring modders on to the team to help.

Speaking of mods, there exists a plethora to choose from. Whether you want to make your game easier, harder, better looking, more realistic, or crazy, there is a mod for you. They include things from graphics overhauls to aerodynamic overhauls to vast quantities of new parts to autopilot systems you code yourself.

The game is both simple and challenging at the same time. It's easy enough to build a rocket, but can you make it fly? Can you get into orbit? How about to the  Moon  Mun? What about  Mars  Duna? The answers may be no at first, but you learn. You slowly understad more and more, and after playing the game for a while, the answer becomes yes. And in that moment, you realize: Hey! I know how space works! This is orbital mechanics! And I know how to do it!" It gives you a wondrous feeling of accomplishment
date: each time you do something new. That feeling barely fades
recommended: as I still feel my heart swell a little every time I land on the Mun.\n\nSo go ahead
hoursPlayed: give the game a shot. It may seem daunting
voteText: but it's really quite fun -- and deceptively simple.\n\nHow hard can rocket science be anyway?"

reviewText:
I came to this came on the wave of Reddit hype a few years ago since then, I have: put it down, deleted, reintalled, flung mice around my room, printed off screenshots and actually shouted in triumph upon landing on the Mun.
The worth of a game, a film, of art in general comes down to the emotional response it elicits. KSP has caused me actual ♥♥♥♥ing trauma, total euphoria, crushing despondancy, childlike wonder, intellectual overreach and many other feelings beyond mere words.
Building a rocket, blowing up said rocket on the launch pad, fixing the staging, running out of fuel before circularising, consulting our Lord Scott Manley, circularising, achieving orbit and just staring out the window at tiny Kerbin before burning retrograde and coming back home.

To recommend this game, is to recommend the spectrum of life's emotions.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm a space enthusiast. I saw a video about KSP which depicted it as a silly and unrealistic game that made fun of serious efforts to explore space. Thankfully, my curiosity got the better of me and I decided to give the game a go. I'm glad I did.

This is a game where I can design, build and fly spacecraft designed any way I like. The game is set in a fictional solar system filled with analogues of planets and moons of our own solar system. I can recreate past and present missions, learning how to land on KSP's Moon analogue, or construct and dock with a space station of my own design. I can also act out proposed future missions by visiting KSP's Mars analogue or other planetary body analogues.

The game is not yet fully mature. We do not yet have realistic re-entry heating. We are not yet able to establish bases to utilise in-situ resources. These features are in development and will be implemented in due course. The next feature we are eagerly awaiting is an overhaul of aerodynamics and implementation of payload fairings and cargo bays.

KSP is realistic without being inaccessible. I'm currently on 1434 hours played without installing any mods.

reviewText: Even with the seemingly impossible challenges, and even harder choice of buying a game that might not seem worth it, I recommend it fully. There's so much for you to do on this game, with its realism, and the hundreds of parts it tosses at you when you open the VAB or Spaceplane Hanger. The planets, moons, and asteriods each have their own challenges and perks that differ from the rest. For example, Duna is farther from Kerbin than the Mun, but Duna has an atmosphere, which allows gliders and rocket planes to fly. The rocket parts and aerodynamics are nothing less than amazing, with engines that benifit and hinder you, fuel tanks that carry diffrent fuel sizes, muiltiple prepulsion methods and more. Not interested in rockets? Well, you got a full hanger with airplane parts choking the catalog. You can still aim for space, however, as it still supplies you with rocket parts, in whice you turn planes into SSTOs (single stage to orbit FYI), and vice versa. The exploration factor is nothing less than infinity. You got 7 planets, most of them with moons. They all have special chractheristics in which you either hate or love. Me myself,  having been  to EVERY planet and moon in this game, has not tired out yet. Why? Instead of just exploring, you can colonize and conquer. You got docking ports, which leads you to massive space stations. You can build bases on explored planets to supply fuel or power to passing ships. This game is truly amazing, even the slightest of space geeks will have fun in this. I recommend it fully 10/10

reviewText: Still charming, now with extra awesomeness.\n\nConstruction UI's gotten even more solid and impressive. Flight model and air resistance and heat management are now unremarkably good (that's a good thing).  Many flight controls are still difficult to discover, but the worst of the old flaws are gone (it no longer trains you to rely on the space bar being do the next thing" only to later on make that an insta-lose-but-only-sometimes button). While you're in-game it still won't show you the keyboard shortcuts and you kinda still have to find out about the quicksave key (F5 save
date: hold-F9 load) yourself before you can go check the keys midflight.  You can't always quicksave.\n\nCaveats as of 1.0.2: This game will enthrall you so thoroughly that _hours_ will pass by.  If you don't  quicksave regularly then sooner or later (leaning towards "sooner") you'll lose an entire evening's meticulous and irreproducible work.  * Quicksave isn't really for exploring different flight plans
recommended: it's for defense against the UI and to a lesser extent some minor bugs. Don't use the hard-mode option that shuts off quicksaves. * Go into the settings input options and shut off the staging function in any but staging mode.  The default setting makes the space bar a pun (but only sometimes): toggle RCS between linear and rotation mode

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe more I play this game, the more I love it. Really, not enough good things can be said about this game. On the surface, it's cute and funny. Go a little deeper and you will find a surprisingly complex and intelligent space simulator, where you will learn something new every time you play it. Honestly, I'd pay twice the price for this much fun. $22.99 is a steal, and 300 hours in, I'm looking at 7 cents per hour for a hell of a good time. The mod community is also very vibrant and adds literally anything you can imagine: new paint jobs, altered physics, communication, fusion-powered engines, warp drives, hyperspace, and even asteroids. Seriously, give this game a shot. You won't regret it.

reviewText: People always talk about making games that are both fun and educational, lets be honest, most fail for one reason or another, not Kerbal! Kerbal space program, Coming in I didn't even understand how much I didn't know about orbital mechanics! But Kerbal space program unravels these secrets in a paced and comprehensive order and most importantly, its fun while doing it.\nEverything from the designing the rocket to performing the actual mission, you don't get near space the first few tries but you feel yourself improving every time, and every stage feels awe inspiring. My first Apollo style moon landing was a highlight to my summer for the sense of acomplishment it entailed.\nEven faliure can be fun, run out of fuel to early? mess up your design and realize after you make it to Duna?(mars), figure out what parts of the mission are salvageable, what science can still be performed. My first mission to Duna ran out of fuel before making into orbit but I was able to use the rotation control rockets to alter my path just enough to fling around its moon and slam into Dunas thin atmosphere to slow myself down. It's that kind of clever problem solving that brings the most satisfaction sometimes.

reviewText:
In Kerbal Space Program the player is tasked with managing their own space program. This generally involves building some sort of craft capable of a specific task and/or reaching one or more bodies in the Kerbol system. It has multiple modes to cater to different playstyles, a simplistic but harsh physics system and a lot of parts for you to choose from when making your contraptions.

The gameThe characters you control, named Kerbals, are cute and most definitely insane. They are the heart and soul of the game, and they seem to like danger a whole lot more than being alive. The brilliance of Kerbal Space Program lies in the way you approach problems. You’re guaranteed to fail almost every time you launch a new craft, and while on paper that doesn’t sound that fun, the game’s revert button allows you to recover from all the launch mistakes and the quick save feature allows you to recover from fatal mistakes on your longer missions. I’d say that most of the fun even comes from your misfortunes: having to send out a second rescue party to send the first and the people originally in danger is something that never ceases to amaze.

The fine printThis game is fairly easy to learn, but it will require a lot of commitment to truly grasp everything you can do in this game. While simplistic, the physics are accurate enough to provide a fair representation of ‘true’ astrophysics, and because it’s so close to real life it shouldn’t take too long to understand what is expected of you.

The scaled down solar system means you will be playing in a lot shorter sessions than you’d otherwise have to, but this game is still very long. Missions can take up to ten hours and beyond. This is most certainly not a game that you can just hop into for a bit. This does mean that this game’s value is insanely high if you’re looking for something to spend a lot of time on. There is no clear end-game, so if you enjoy the game enough you could end up playing it forever.

This game is really easy to mod. So any problems you have with it can be solved by installing more mods, and they often also add content: anything from EVA construction to colonisation to FTL drives. You name it, there’s probably a mod out there for it.

The game’s performance is good, with a few bugs here and there. None of them are gamebreaking though, and most of them are due to the engine. I’m hopeful of what Unity 5 will do for this game, but even with Unity 4 this game will run on a lot of systems. Because the game isn’t a graphical powerhouse it actually runs quite well on laptops, but the processor does need to be good to handle all the physics.

Summary+ High value for money
+ A large amount of parts to choose from
+ Simple yet fun physics

- Long play sessions
- A few bugs

ConclusionWhether you like building insane contraptions, setting up missions to places far away, or just have an unreasonable obsession with space you will find a lot to like in this game. And who knows, maybe you’ll even pick up a thing or two about how spaceflight works.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is seriously one of the greatest creations of the modern era. Design, build and fly your rockets into space, the moon and beyond. With multiple planets and accompanying moons to explore. Build space stations like the ISS or a moonbase, all with docking capabilities. Then take your little Kerbals out for a space walk and plant flags at your landing sites. With a massive and very active moding community, the only limitation is your imagination.

Recently added was the career mode, where you start off with limited parts to build with and you have to venture forth doing science experiment to aquire science points to unlock new or improved parts. You can then build bigger and better vessels, so you can go further and do MORE SCIENCE!!

You buy this game right now!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

How hard could it be? It's only rocket science. If the idea of putting parts to build various flying machines in appealing you you I highly recommend you try this out. It's a got a bit of learning curve but it is worth it. To make things easier on yourself you can skip the in-game tutorials (they mostly confused me) and hop on YouTube instead. Scott Manley has a good tutorial series. This is the link for the playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLYu7z3I8tdEmqpOkQZCl5SZB5t0vXuxE0

You'll probably want to at least make some attempts at flying prior to jumping to the videos as a lot of the fun of the game can come from failure and cool explosions... not that you'll have a shortage of those later. Rescue missions on distant worlds make for some amusing challenges.
