reviewText:
Early Access Review

My most rewarding gaming experience ever comes from rescuing one of my kerbals, trapped on the Mun after a routine science mission had a rough landing, damaging the parachutes of the vessel and rendering it incapable of returning to Kerbin. The rescue mission had to be quick as the life support (TAC life support mod) was running out for Jebadiah Kerman. After rendevousing with the damaged ship in a low Munar orbit, the rescue vessel set about returning to Kerbin with much less fuel than planned. It was tooth and nails as the vessel only just managed to deorbit itself, skimming through Kerbin's atmosphere multiple times before finally landing, all astronauts safe.

That is the thing about Kerbal Space Program, everyone has a story about the game which they want to tell. You design your own missions- they go well, success! they go wrong, rescue mission! You design ships and redesign them. You plan your missions, and you fly those missions.

The game is still being developed and new features are gradually getting rolled out. And if you ever want more, the awesome modding community has you covered, adding ♥♥♥♥-loads of more content and gameplay, from extra parts to requiring life support for kerbals or even a connection link for unmanned vessels.

P.S. I recommend checking out Scott Manley's youtube videos for tutorials and to just see someone who does awesome things in the game.

Kerbal Space Program basically sums up the entire reason as to why I wish I were an astronaut/rocket scientist, and the entire reason as to why there is no way in hell I could ever be one.

The game has two modes (as of the time of this writing), Career, and Sandbox.  Sandbox is exactly what it sounds like, minus the cat poop and the lost action figures (never forget you little Anakin!).  In sandbox, you build a rocket ship or a space plane, and you go to space. reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you like space, science and space science you'll love this magical little gem of a game. It's *not* easy, which I happen to like. I'm sick of games that I can beat in a matter of hours. Kerbal Space Program is hard - hard as ♥♥♥♥ in some cases - and as such it can be incredibly rewarding to land on a new planet, moon, or just build a cool new thing.

There are some fairly significant downsides:

1. The tutorials are terrible. Maybe I'm just stupid? I ended up having to figure most of the game out myself and spent tons of time looking things up on YouTube and the game's Wiki.

2. It's a *little* slow to start. Because the controls are a bit obscure at first I wasn't sure I was going to like it. I ended up playing it immediately after buying it, becoming frustrated and shelving it for about two weeks. But I am *SO* glad I gave it a second chance.

3. There're still some weird bugs, but the KSP team seems quite active in working them out. It's still only just now in beta so bugs are to be expected. Unfortunately the worst one I've encountered managed to corrupt my best saves, forcing me to start over after having a nearly completed tech tree.

However I haven't had this problem again in over a month now - maybe it was fixed, maybe I'm just lucky.

Anyway, despite these problems, the game is ABSOLUTELY worth every penny and I'm incredibly excited for future content and witnessing the continuing development of this game. Obviously as a video game it's not quite the same thing as actually being an astronaut, an engineer or ground control, but it does give you an entirely new appreciation for what NASA, the ESA, Roscosmos, and any other space agency do every day. It *is* rocket science! Just a touch dumbed down for those of us without Ph.Ds :D

Build all the things.

Buy all the Kerbal Space Programs.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Whilst still technically in Alpha, I don't think a game has had me coming back to it with every patch this often since Minecraft! Beta release is just around the corner but I do hope they continue to add more things. That's not to say there isn't a lot there already... but the potential is huge!

Regarding the game itself... build it, fly it, crash it. Build it again, fly it again, crash it again. Things will go wrong, adjustments will need to be made, and kerbals will get lost in space. It's ok though because that means you can try to rescue them! When that fails, try to rescue both ships at the same time with a bigger ship! In no time you'll have space debris surrounding your home planet, but in the process you'll learn orbital mechanics, docking proceedures and the best landing techniques for the dozens of planets in the system at present. Then there are asteroids too! Give this game a shot, if you don't want to pay out right away I believe there's a demo available from the main website.

reviewText:
After having played this extensively in the beta, and now adding plenty of time to that post release from early-access, really all that can be said is how amazingly ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed wonderful this game is.

Underneath what can only be descibed as a charming, humurous exterior lies an incredibly deep, physics based strategy game that basically leaves you to it. You will fail to get a ship in to orbit dozens of times before you ever make it into space, but that's purely because you haven't figured it out yet, which, when you do, makes it so much more rewarding.

Each small step makes way for a bigger step, and then an even bigger step, until you're exploring the entire solar system, putting stations in orbit around far-flung gas giants and somehow managing to make a return trip to the surface of Eve. At the same time, you learn so much about space exploration - when was education ever remotely this fun?

A thoroughly amazing game and very much worth of much of your time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is very hard to describe as it is one of a kind.
I could label it as a space program simulator but that really doesn't do Kerbal Space Program justice.

Kerbal Space Program is essentially a game about managing your own space program, building your own rockets, planes, ships, space stations, landers, or any silly contraption you imagine really, and taking your poor victims.. err Kerbals.. to the stars!
It runs on a semi-realistic physics and astronomy system where you can see every single part of your ship explode spectacularly as your poor Kerbals show their expressions of despair throughout the ride.
This is a game about building and exploring the Kerbal Solar System and each of it's astral bodies, about making silly contraptions and planting flags on unexplored worlds.

And if you ever want to go beyond the far reaches of the solar system, there's also a plethora of mods already available for Kerbal Space Program despite it being only in alpha stage... Even a multiplayer mod.

I haven't sinked as many hours into a single videogame for a very long time as I did with Kerbal Space Program.


This is Rocket Science the videogame and is an ABSOLUTE MUST!


WARNING SIDE-EFFECTS:
You will learn a few concepts of aerodynamics, physics and astronomy just by having fun!

reviewText:
This game is very unique and extremely fun. It is very challenging, but also extremely satisfying when you accomplish something. In addition, it quite expands your knowledge about physics.

There is no other game like this, but in some ways it bears similarities to Dwarf Fortress - both games have sharp learning curve, are extremely difficult beyond the very basics (albeit KSP is pretty forgiving) and the lesson you learn from them is that losing is fun.

KSP simulates physics very well, it includes objects burning when reentering atmosphere, different gravity on various bodies, and the whole solar system is actually simulated (planets and asteroids orbiting Sun, moons orbiting planets), while the game is a sandbox allowing you to do whatever you want. Do you want to fly to the Moon? Sure. Do you want to do research on an asteroid? Sure. Do you want to take that asteroid down  to Earth? Sure! (But it's not gonna be easy!)

Oh, and you do actually learn some physics in the game. You have to. This, however, lets you understand space exploration and why is it so difficult and takes so much time. After all, in KSP you get to do a lot of stuff yourself!

The game doesn't have any drawbacks either. Perhaps some rare bugs or crashes, but very few. Other than that, the game is flawless.

It's not just the best space game. It's actually one of the best games ever made. I recommend it to literally everyone. Download a demo to try it out first and fly to the Moon.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you are interested in space travel, and astrophysics, try this game!You might learn something. Or, if you are already an expert, you can see with your own eyes how these things really work. Of course, not everything is modelled perfectly, for example, you don't have to worry about the heat during re-entry, the aerodynamic drag works in a kind of a gamey way, and I can guarantee you that some of your earliest designs are gonna resemble a soft, shaking sausage instead of a rocket, but at the end of the day, you are gonna feel like you just built a real rocket.

If you are interested in original, deep, addictive, sometimes awe-inspiring games, TRY THIS GAME!!When your build your first orbit-capable rocket.
Your first spacewalk.
When you first reach Mün.
Your first modular space-station.
When you first flip and crash your rover on the surface of another planet.
When you learn about the fantastic stuff OTHER PEOPLE can build in this game.
Just some of the great moments you'll experience in KSP.
The game might look complicated, and yes, you CAN build some pretty complicated stuff, but the learning curve is surprisingly easy, of course watching some youtube videos help a lot.
Graphically, it's one of the most beautiful games I've ever seen. Yes, the textures are not really detailed, the models aren't, either, but when you first align your rocket against the Sun so you can only see a silhouette, with your pilot next to it on an EVA, when you drive your Rover through Mün's canyon, or when you turn the lights on on your shiny new space station are as screenshot-worthy moments as anything ever.
The building possibilites are endless, especially with the great mods out there. Of course, so are the possibilities to explode right at the launch pad. ;)

Seriously, try this game, playing KSP is one of the most special experiences any game can give.

EDIT: Oh, and don't be bothered by the fact that it's still Early Access, the game is constantly evolving, and felt like a finished game even months ago.

reviewText:
Kerbal has a steep learning curve, but once you've figured out the mechanics, the reward of plotting out & achieving a goal is one the best experiences I've had in gaming in years!

In the space of 40 hours, I started off barely managing to launch a rocket several thousand feet into the air. Now I'm fully capable of being able to both create a space faring craft & plot a course to recover a stranded astronaut circling around the orbit of the Mun (Kerbal's moon) over several million miles away.

This isn't even scratching the surface of future possibilities I could attempt. I could perform a moon landing. Lift & place a space station into a stable orbit or travel to several of the other planetary bodies in the solar system.

Much like an advanced 'Banjo Kazooie Nuts & Bolts' there's very little hand holding with a bare minimum of instruction of how to perform any of these outrageous feats. It takes the right combination of a well designed vessel, a correctly plotted route of orbital eclipses, skillful piloting & finally luck. Once you have all these, it's not long before you're complimenting yourself on a job well done & planning out what your next grand project is going to be.

With charming & fluid presentation, extensive & encouraged mod support, atmospheric soundtrack & both career plus sandbox mode included. There's very little this game does wrong.

You'll be doing yourself a disservice not giving this game a go!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Kerbal Space Program (KSP) is really awesome, if you are into space exploration the non-fictional way.
Your imagination is not limited.
You can practically send anything into space or on other celestial bodies.
This is, if it is able to leave the surface of your home planet without exploding... ;-)
Most people like to play the game just for fun, sending rockets and crews up into orbit or to the Mun (the moon of the planet Kerbin, where your Space Center is located).
You can gather science there to either way collect data or enhance your research of new technologies and rocket-/plane-parts, if you play career-mode (rather then sandbox mdoe, where you already habe all parts) or you can just do it FTW!

Be warned the learning curve is pretty steep, which means you will have some hard lessons to learn, until you really pull of your first spaceflight.

Nontheless this should not hinder you in downloading the DEMO first and try out if you have the guts to send Kerbal"s into space or not. ;-)
Kerbals are the little eggheads doing funny facial expressions to the right lower screen.
The most famous is Jebediah Kerbin (aka Jeb).
He will be your first voluntary (test-)pilot.

This game is for all ages and space enthusiast

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One of the first games to get on the Early Access bus, and one of the very few to actually do a good job of it. KSP is a brilliant little game for everyone from clueless cosmo-naughts to astrophysicists. It's also remarkably versatile, so boats, rovers, and planes are all things too. The mechanics are solid, the graphics aren't too rough considering the game's scale, and there is a vibrant and diverse modding community.

Easily one of the best gaming purchases you can make, as long as you don't mind days of your life being consumed by the need to put little green men into space.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Quite the revolutionary game if you ask me. Not only do you get to build your own rockets, spaceplanes, and whatever else you can think of. You can also build your own learning curve as well! With the help of modifications that make the base game even easier or more difficult!

Cannot get to the mun? Get a mod that can change engine specific impulse so you can travel further!

Planted a flag on every planet and moon? Get a mod that makes the Kerbol system resemble ours on a 1:1 scale!

Game crashing because of too many mods? There is a mod to fix that!

Once you have mastered KSP in all it's glory there is still fun to be had. Especially because there are many things to master in the base game like: docking, spaceplanes, and of course not running out of fuel before reaching your destination so you can return to Kerbin. The community, and modmakers only make the game even more in depth and fun!

You don't like modding your game? Kudos to you vanilla extremist, I still haven't even done everything in stock KSP yet. Just goes to show how much fun you can have in this game with plenty of things to do! Well worth it's price!

10/10 Still haven't touched the spaceplane hangar

reviewText:
Kerbal Space Program is the perfect combination between gaming, learning and the best damn community a game can wish for. With almost unlimited mods and tutorials you're pretty much settled to spend a load of fun hours in this game.

The only negative point in my opinion is that for some people the challenge will be too much. You don't just go to the moon or fly by an interstellar planet like that, there will be a lot of planning, thinking and most of all; failure. Seriously, the difficulty of this game can make you lose your ♥♥♥♥. Imagine this: you're a wedding planner and you've been planning for days, only to discover that you're one cupcake short when the wedding is almost over and because of this you can start all over. It's a bit like that, but can you imagine the satisfaction when you actually pull something off? It's a feeling no other game can give you, trust me.

Also, what I mentioned before, the community is amazing. Ever heard of Scott Manley? You will after you buy this game. There are many more like him that make tutorials for doing the craziest stuff, and a load of others that make humorous video's using KSP. Then there are mods, that can make the experience that much more challenging, fun or realistic.

So all together, I would definitely recommend this game. Unless of course you don't like a challenge that will tear your family apart. Have fun :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have followed Kerbal Space Program for a long time and it has gone from a good game to epic! It's tricky to master but you are rewarded every step of the way and it's not even final release! My favourite single player game of all time.

Now ver1 is out! Wow... what can I say, it's better than I could have hoped for. Everything that makes KSP so special has been fused together with epicness. I fail to see how you can not love it, the cute little green men, the disasters, the sucess and true freedom. Go whereever you like, build what ever you want, fail, suceed and just have too much fun. If KSP was a drug it would be tobacco. I have to remind myself it's just a single player game because it sits up there with the best games of all time not just single player games.

Beauty: Every player who playes KSP will have a different path to sucess or failure. There is no right way in KSP, you build what you can to get the job done. Trial and error and even with 2000+ hours on KSP I have not built the perfect rocket because there is no perfect. If you forget an antenna or a parachute etc your mission will fail but this is how you learn.

As for the new ver 1 mining stuff 10/10 it's just so polished as a game I cant praise the game enough, fantastic+epic!

reviewText:
Oh my Science....

This is... BY FAR....

My favorite video game of the current era.

Those who know me, know I'm a rabid Fallout and Resident Evil fangirl. I can't call this game my favorite yet (Fallout 2 still has this title by a steady grasp) but KSP is a very close follower.

To sum up the entirety of this game in a few phrases or memes....

This game = NASA + Lemmings.
KSP is hollywood rocket science....
collect ALL THE SCIENCE!

There are 3 modes of play. The first mode is sandbox. You get all the parts unlocked, you can build anything you can think of, and then explode it marvellously while trying to fire it up into space. The second mode, is Science mode. This unlocks the Tech Tree and the collection of science. Parts are restricted by the Tech Tree, visitable through the R&D building. Collecting science unlocks branches in the Tech Tree. This gives you access to more and more parts, until you're eventually at the end of the tree, and its basically like Sandbox mode. The third is Career Mode. Career is the fully unlocked version of the game, requiring you to balance limited parts (locked behind the Tech Tree, requiring the collection of Science), limited money (Rocket science is expensive! Ships now cost money, and you have limited funding. In order to get more money, you need to complete missions from the Mission Control building), and spontaneous explosive deconstruction.

The whole point of the game is to explore the Kerbol system. Its that simple. Build rockets, leave the planet Kerbin (third from the sun Kerbol), and visit all you can. The Kerbol System has 8 planets, Moho (like Mercury), Eve (Venus analogue), Kerbin (Earth-like), Duna (Mars rip-off), Dres (Small planet, light gravity, hard to land on), Jool (Jupiter wannabe), and Eeloo (Pluto if it was a planet!). Each planet has its own special features, moons, things to see, and difficulties in visiting.

The game has an INCREDIBLE modding community, which I recommend, and the YouTube community loves making crafts and blowing them up. I VERY MUCH invite you to watch Scott Manley's videos for learning Kerbal science and aerodynamics.... skills needed to blow up much less often than before!

The game still has its issues... I commonly find the Hell Kraken or ♥♥♥ Kraken (Community known bugs), but this may be due to the mods installed on my game.  The Windows x64 version is horribly broken, but the other versions are great.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Kerbal space program is a physics sandbox space simulator. You can build ships or planes using individual parts such as engines, fuel tanks, solar panels etc. Planets are almost realistically sized and so is the space between them. You can build space stations, send probes to intercept the moon or some how build a manned base on the gas giant 'Jool'.

If you ever get bored of the game then you can visit the space port website where you can download hundreds of modifications to the game, including physics changing ones!

reviewText:
One of my favourite games of all time... back when it still was in Early Access with version number 0.23 or 0.24.2. After that pretty much all the developers have done is integrating some mods and putting boobs on a kerbal (but no boob-physics, so you can't study how boobs jiggle in space. So what's the point of female kerbals. Except to push the feminist ideology down your throat.)
Also I'm a Sandbox-guy, who doesn't give a damn about Career or Science mode (Though I'm also the only guy in the community who ♥♥♥♥ing hates Jebediah Kerman, or any one of those orange suited kerbals), just let me fly planes and spaceships.

But enough of ranting. In a nutshell this is a game where you build stuff and then crash them. Rovers, Planes, Rockets, Starships, whatever you desire. Also Satellites, Space Stations and unmanned probes.

Graphics may not be the best there are, but that doesn't stop the game from being mindblowingly stunning. The first time you achieve orbit (it's not that hard) and look down. If you enjoyed Gravity or Interstellar in theaters, you'll like this game.

Though even with all the new nuisances I still recommend this game as it still is pretty fun.

Just make sure you get some mods.
Install one mod and start your own asteroid mining corporation.
Another mod and start colonizing other worlds.
Third one and you got yourself an Apollo 11 replica.
Fourth mod to build a bloody Borg cube.
Fifth, sixth and seventh for GPS system, Deep Space Telescope and a Mapping satellite.
The list goes on and on.

And now, I'm off to the internet to find a previous version of this game along with some compatible mods and without female kerbals.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After one and half year since my last review at 0.25, I am pretty amazed about how this game has changed. Careers, more parts, better aerodynamics and heating simulation.
What I loved better is the amazing modders. Plugins and parts are always growing better, taking shapes and functioning more smoothly. Ferram4, bac9, Acea, BahamutoD, those guys are just getting more amazing than ever making more and more fantastic mods.
Since 1.1 is almost out of the bakery, this indie game is making it's way through!



====Previous review at 0.25 [Sept.2014]====
Well, after a total of 100 hours of gaming time (steam doesn't count every time I started it directly from the directory), I was proud to say that I am finally a amateur engineer and pilot. In the gaming process, I found this game quite challenging despite earlier easy experience.
Generally, it's a pretty nice game though it's still in dev. Much of the game is something like Space Engineer, but this one is quite realistic(if you got some mods installed). Also, the game's setting is a highlight. A vast system of star, planets, asteroids and moons. Impressive if you like exploring. Also, the orbit and aerodynamic is just as great as its inspiring game, Orbiter.
The game is developed on Unity platform, and the x64 edition is just realeased and packed with some bugs, severe or unimportant. If it simply crashed or a Oops message appears, don't worry. It's just a bug ruining your game experience. But don't blame the dev team please! They are trying their best to make everything perfect, although it's just a Good" now. Oh

reviewText:
I have decided to edit my review, in light of (a TON) of new content since i last posted.
------------

Is the game fun:... its basically a drug.
is it easy?: no.  not at all. in fact this will be the biggest issue people have with the game. while Dark souls is hard in a quick reflexes or death" kind of way.... KSP is hard in a "omg i dont understand this
date:
what on earth is a Pe and DeltaV?!" kind of way.

One of the biggest issues new people to this game have is that well.... its rocket science. and most of us didn't walk into this game with a couple degrees. (though i feel like i could get one walking out)

as a result there has been a huge disconnect for many people between the "what i need to know to enjoy this" and "what i actually know right now". amd this has caused many people to not enjoy there experience
recommended: or to quit the game altogether.\n\nNow with version 1.1
hoursPlayed: this issue has been addressed with an in game "wiki" if you will.  the rocket science 101
voteText: the up goers guide to the galaxy. and man did they hit it out of the park.\n\nnot only is it super detailed.... i mean like
helpfulPercent: detailed enough that despite having 1500 hours logged in game on steam alone (dont judge me) i was still able to learn something i didn't know flipping its pages.\n\nbut it is implemented in a way that makes it not only easy to access
votesHelpful: and easy to use.... but basically screams "use me". right down to having a built in pause game button into the wiki
votesTotal: so you have the option of flipping a few pages on route to kill time... or to pause the game in a panic as you try to figure out why your 1 rocket just became 5.\n\nand yet
votesFunny: with all of that
commentsCount: its still super easy to follow.  I am glad they have finally cast away that looming shadow that has haunted this game for years and fixed one of the last real issues this game faced.\n\nand if you are wondering
column16: yes.... the rest of the game is amazing too."

reviewText:
I'm in SPAAAaace ! This is by far the best space simulation game ever made, but forget space combat : the only fight will be your limited knowledge about space newtonian physics.

The base game is very fun, and evolves with every new version in a most satisfying way. Then you can add community Plugins, and gods there are many good ones ! Create a communication network to pilot your probes around the solar system. Map the planets and asteroids to prepare your ground missions. Do science. Then create a gigantic asteroid mining base, a fuel reloading orbital station, and drive your ships even further on distant celestial objects.

You will have to deal with the limitations of your science at the beginning to fulfill your contracts, but the more science you unlock, the further you will be able to go in your space odyssey.

Give it a try, I don't think you'll be disappointed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Chaplins last 'silent' film, filled with sound effects, was made when everyone else was making talkies. Charlie turns against modern society, the machine age, (The use of sound in films ?) and progress. Firstly we see him frantically trying to keep up with a production line, tightening bolts. He is selected for an experiment with an automatic feeding machine, but various mishaps leads his boss to believe he has gone mad, and Charlie is sent to a mental hospital... When he gets out, he is mistaken for a communist while waving a red flag, sent to jail, foils a jailbreak, and is let out again. We follow Charlie through many more escapades before the film is out.

Review paid for by: Time Warner Cable

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What can I say about Kerbal Space Program.

This game is a must have if you like creating things, experimenting with things, doing funny things with funny looking creatures, or just want to learn, this game is a must have.

In this game, a player can either choose Sandbox mode (most like creative mode in Minecraft) where all the parts are unlocked and available, or Career mode where the player has to create rockets that can collect Science! to get more parts to get more Science!.

If you know what you are doing, great. This game is fun if you do. If not, this game is even more fun, as you have no idea what an apoapsis or periapsis is and how to calculate delta-v, which usually turns into a mission that requires a lot of manuvering, which teaches the player later on. Don't give up if you cannot accomplish what you are trying to do. Try again! This game will waste the time away with incredible fun.

Overall score: 9.5/10

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI can honestly say this is one of the most enjoyable games recently developed that I have ever seen. A steep learning curve means progress can be slow and difficult, but overcoming challenges become all the more rewarding as a result. You have the options to build spacecraft that are simple, complex, brilliant, insane, or a combination of all four. Then you get to fly what you've built and see whether you need to change the design, or merely how you fly it. With a community that is usually eager to help those who struggle, feedback and advice is seldom out of reach. I highly recommend this game if you're into space exploration and are not afraid of a challenge.

Early Access Review

I really love this game. It is like you are NASA and all of its employees. You get to design and build the rockets, spaceships, and planes and then fly them. I am currently doing missions to explore and land on the moons of what would be Jupiter in the game, and I can still see a lot of content left for me to explore.

Once you get into the game a bit, I highly suggest looking into downloading some mods for the game, since it has a pretty strong modding community.

This game teaches you geometry, planetary motion, the effects of gravity in space and much, much more. I find myself using my calculator to plan my missions and drawing up mission outlines. Success in the game takes a smart mind and a good plan. I think it is one of the best games I have ever played.

I highly recommed it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Kerbal Space Program is close to my idea of a perfect game. It's a beautiful fusion of rocket science, physics, and just the right amount of lunacy to make for an extremely entertaining and engrossing game.

Although the game is unfinished, and it can be painfully obvious at some times, the core mechanics in place are amazing enough to make you overlook those shortcomings as you play.

If you have ever had an interest in physics or space, this game is for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pros:
+Totally open ended, build whatever sort of rockets you like.
+Persistent universe, rockets you send up today can serve as docking platforms or refueling stations for things you send tomorrow.
+Fun cartoon aesthetic.
+Built-in procedural quest system (Contracts) always available to give you new goals.  They're totally optional, you can fly wherever your fuel will take you.
+This game taught me orbital mechanics.

Cons:
-Rough optimization.  You may need a beefy rig especially if you want to make big complicated rockets.  However a small rocket can complete most of the in game challenges and is kinder on your system.
-Control scheme can take some getting used to.  Everything is rebindable though.
-Dedication to realism means that you're sometimes hitting the time compression button and waiting (and waiting) for an orbital launch window to open.  However this is only an issue for distant planets.  The moon is always nearby and ready to explore.

This game doesn't hold your hand because there's not one (or even ten) correct answers to any problem.  You may find certain tasks like getting a stable orbit or docking with another craft challenging, but there's literally hundreds of cheerful, informative youtube vids offering tips.  And if it starts hard, you'll feel like a boss when you finally nail it.

reviewText:
What a fantastic game!

I have been playing since early beta and had the pleasure of watching this game blossom into what it is today.

If you enjoy building and tinkering, planes and rockets, space exploration, and many, many explosions, then this game is definitely for you!

You have the pleasure of building the Kerbal Space Program from the ground up. Starting from your very first rocket exploding on the pad, you will soon be taking your Kerbals to distant planets with full blown multi-stage ships, and planning trans orbital maneuvers like you had been doing it all your life.

If I were new to KSP, I think my only complaint would be the lack of a thorough tutorial. The player is really left to fend for themselves as far as using features goes. There is a lot to learn about controlling and building your craft, and most of it has to be done by trial and error. Fortunately there are plenty of community resources for KSP, so a short Google search will get you past any features you are having trouble with.

This game will certainly be a joy to play. Definitely recommended for anyone with a mind to download it.
voteText: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is amazing and if you are thinking about buying it, you should. It is still in development and the developers are adding many new features in 2014, among them are big ticket features such as multiplayer are planned. The community is very helpful and there is a large proportion of mods and tutorials available online. If you enjoy sandbox oriented games, do not look far, for this game has both sandbox and objective oriented modes.

Bugs do happen, but are not as frequent and disastrous as one might expect, and often go unnoticed.

Kerbal Space Program is well rounded, often humorous, and overall fun and easily enjoyable. I myself took almost a solid 10 hours getting to the Mün, and while it was extremely painful to watch myself fail time and time again, it was enjoyable to just build vehicles bound only by physics.

reviewText:
Possibly one of the best games to be released in the last 10 years. I have for a very long time dreamed of going to space and this game only strengthen's that desire. Here's my analysis of this game.

Graphics: Have improved dramatically compared to what they were back when I started playing. The Mun has changed shape for crying out loud!

Gameplay: With the recently improved aerodynamics, The gameplay is superb. Watching your own rocket/spaceplane tumble back to Kerbin is an amazing feeling.

Other: Contracts are wonderful. However, they feel a little repetitive in the late game. The tech tree is fun to explore and great for first time players. When multiplayer comes out I wont be surprised if I rack up 2000+ hours on here. If I were a therapist I would recommend this game to my patients because of how great you feel when you finally land on the Mun that required 5 Kerbal's lives to get there, and then planning a rescue mission!

The rundown: Buy this immediately.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

October Sky

Oh! I have slipped the surly bonds of Earth, well Kerbin actually, but more on that later.

Whether you actively seek out information on the inspiring missions carried out by the various space agencies around the globe or just catch the odd news report on the latest mars rover or comet flyby, you can't help but feel a certain sense of awe at the ingenuity and creativity that has led to these missions of exploration and discovery.

Now we all have the opportunity to experience the glorious highs and devastating lows of running our own space program through Squads Kerbal Space Program.

When you load KSP you'll be presented with a choice of three play modes. There's a full career mode where you'll have to design and launch your own missions, invest in research for new rocket parts and complete contracts for their financial rewards to help fund all of this.

There a Science only mode, where you can still enjoy the progression of the science tree without having to worry about balancing the books and then there's a sandbox mode, where you can let your creativity run wild without the restrictions of the other two options.


Space Camp

Taking the plunge with the career mode, you'll first need to choose your fledgling space agencies name and flag logo.
You'll then find yourself looking down at your shiny new space agency campus. At present, you'll start with 3 wannabe astronauts, a very limited amount of rocket parts and an even more limited budget.

The first thing you'll probably want to do is take a look at the contracts available to you. These have specific requirements which when met will reward you both financially and often with a scientific reward which you can invest in the tech-tree.


Astronaut Farmer

Pick your first contract, Launch a craft from your launch pad and achieve an altitude of 5000m." It's then time to bolt a cockpit to rusty tank of rocket fuel
date: glue an engine to the bottom of the stack
recommended: light the touch paper and step back from the launch pad.\n\nIf everything goes to plan
hoursPlayed: your first rocket will fly straight and true (although not very high yet
voteText: you're going to need better engines and tanks before you can achieve anywhere near orbital height).\nOf course if things didn't go to plan
helpfulPercent: you could be looking a pretty fireball and a smattering of debris raining down around your complex.\n\nLet's assume things went perfectly
votesHelpful: you're aspiring astronaut has earned his wings and returned safely back to the ground courtesy of the parachute you remembered to fit to the capsule. Not only this but your managed to achieve the required 5000 metres
votesTotal:
completed your first contract and received the payment.

Now it's time to visit the tech tree and plan your next mission.


Space Cowboys

As you progress through the game and your missions become more adventurous you will find a full
votesFunny: well balanced and very interesting tech tree to unlock

However each rocket part costs money and at the moment we still don't have very much

Several completed contracts and a few catastrophic failures later and our space agency is about to earn its stripes. We've managed to send various science packages to different biomes on Kerbin

reviewText:
An excellent space simulation game with tons of user-made contents and mods existed. Learning curve is quite steep, but once you understand it the experience is priceless. Some of the features are much simplified from real life rocket science due to technical and gameplay reasons (no n-body physics, less punishing air resistance model, etc), yet it is still quite challenging for beginners (including me lol).

While the vanilla version of the game is already almost perfect, it is greatly improved by the mod supports. There are tons of contents and mods in the repository, like adding a far more realistic physics (better air resistance model, realistic planet size, experimental n-body system), adding sci-fi and far-future engines (like Alcubierre warp drive and wormholes),  adding new robot parts (yes, you can build Macross' Valkyrie and Gundam) and adding a whole new exoplanet system. Heck, there are even programming mods if you want to challenge yourself to fly your own space ships just by code!

So, in Kerbal Space Program, the sky is not the limit.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very fun game! Been playing for a year in early access and if you are into true Sandbox games that allow you to explore the world and universe around you, this is the game for you!

You basically build whatever you want/need to get your ship to do what you wanted it to do, whether is building massive interplanetary rockets or space planes that can leave orbit and fly inside the planets atmosphere, or even send a space station in orbit to refuel and restock, all from scrap!

The one thing the game does lack is direction or a mission type system to give the player purpose beyond building their dream ships. A career mode is in the works but doesn't provide goals beyond researching matter throught the galaxy.

I'd recomend this game to anyone who is into sci-fi, space exploration, engineering, and simulation games.

8/10 rating.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Space; the final frontier. We might not be able to explore our solar system, launch countless space stations and monsterous rockets in real life, but virtually anything is possible in Kerbal Space Program. This is ultimately how an early access game should be done, and I'm writing this on the launch day of 1.0 as it's coming out of Beta. It's come a long way with a massive community of modders out there, which thankfully are not going to turn into paid mods--and developers who listen to, as well as have hired members of the community to help with the game.

It can be relentless, it can be fun, and at times hilarious. Whether you're an absolute beginner, have some rudimentary knowledge of rocketry--this can be great for people of all playing styles and ages. You also don't have to dedicate a whole lot of time--jump in for 5 minutes, or a few hours.

Want to just blow up rockets? That's fine.
Space Station nut with no goal of exploration? You're missing out, but that's fine too.
Are you like me and love building entire networks of probes and satellites? Ah, that's fun and quite the challenge.

The experience is quite something unique, and I can't recommend this enough. Pick it up as soon as you can.

reviewText:
Most likely the best space simulator ever made.

While there is a bit of a learning curve and it may take a while to actually be successful and good at the game, I do still highly recommend this to anyone with an itch or desire to build things and explore outer space. One of the best sandbox games out there with a campaign mode.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have over 150 hours in this game.

One hundred and fifty hours of...Building rockets, exploding rockets, trying to get to space, being flung out of the universe at over 400KM/s, orbiting planets. Building rovers, crashing rovers, stealing Asteroids and bringing them back to Kerbin and then flying to them WITH A SPACE PLANE.

All those hours playing with little green men, having a blast solving the challenge of Space Travel.  Building sensible rockets that obey physics and get to space on-the-cheap (Can YOU get to Orbit on 30,000 Kerbal bucks?)...And then saying **** it all and spending 3 Million on the most absurd contraption, and sending it into a crash course with the moon.


For ever bit of amazing (albeit scaled-down) realism and sensible design, crafting, progression and potentially educational (And I mean that earnestly--I have learned a LOT about space, orbits, and interplanetary travel from this game)---It always carries the flip side of just slapping hundreds of rockets together until it's so big it breaks the launch pad and time itself.

Buy it. Learn something.  Blow something up, and then repeat from Step 2.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Imagine for a moment, space travel with a complete disregard for safety. Instead of tirelessly assessing rockets to see if they will work, engineers just throw something together, plop some astronaughts in it, and send it on its way, often to a fiery end. Instead of checking fuel lines, or decouple joints, or even just the ability of a rocket to stay together, astronaughts get stranded in deep space when the command pod gets ejected instead of the empty fuel tanks, or the rockets break off from the rest of the spaceship and swoosh off into space. No calculations are made to ensure that the rocket has enough fuel to travel to it's destination, and mission after mission fails to even achieve orbit.

That is Kerbal Space program.

Trial and error is the name of the game (wait, isn't it called KSP?), and explosions are often the goal. If your first launch doesn't cause a Kerbonaught (Kerbals are the ingame species of space travellers) to die in horrific fashion, or leave most of the rocket on the launch pad because of an explosive malfunction, you are doing something wrong (or more accurately, right).

Essentially, if you enjoy space travel and designing contraptions (as sometimes you don't want a rocket, maybe a VTOL is more your style), this game is for you. If you enjoy setting your own goals and then setting them lower, this game is for you. If you are a rocket scientist, or if you are not a rocket scientist, this game is for you.

I suppose if you prefer to do things right, you can enjoy this game too. With the help of mods and/or a good understanding of space travel, you can easily develop rockets that work, but it is still very rewarding. Instead of trying to even crash into the Mun (in-game Moon) you can rather focus on building a space station around Jool (in-game Jupiter), or make the game harder by adding life support and communication networks.

Now, this game is not instant gratification, and it is not easy. If you prefer quick games, easy games, or games with specific goals, KSP may not be for you, but if you have even the slightest interest in space travel, buy this game, you will not regret it. KSP is a truly fantastic space program sim, simplified enough to make it fun, but still very focused on the true fundementals of rocketry: orbital mechanics, thrust to weight, specific impulse etc. (And trust me, if you get addicted, you'll figure out what those things all mean).

So throw caution to the wind and launch your skyscraper, or bring an asteroid crashing down to Kerbin (in-game Earth), or fly some kerbonaughts into the sun, it's your choice, and the sky isn't even close to the limit (or that would make for boring rocketry).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There are two ways to play Kerbal Space Program. One involves planning, calculations and patience. The alternative is to ignore the wealth of learning material on offer and instead combine large amounts of rocket thrusters with a reckless abandon for the lives of your crew. I chose the latter.

KerbalSpaceProgramFlightFailure arrives in many forms when you play Kerbal Space Program, surprising you when you least expect it. You can run out of fuel, land too fast, or simply build a rocket that is inherently doomed to rip itself apart. Watching rockets crash into things at high speeds is fun, but it’s heartbreaking to have your flight end in disaster after committing time to the rest of the journey.

Luckily the ship building system is easy to use so you should be able to put together something which is vaguely flyable. Parts clip neatly together, and there are a range of fuel tanks, thrusters, and cockpits from which to choose. The two main types of vehicle are space planes and rockets, but you can also build wheeled vehicles, space stations, and satellites. You build rockets in stages, so that you can jettison fuel containers as they are emptied. Carrying dead weight into orbit is likely to doom your mission, so you’ll need to design your stages carefully.

Kerbal Space Program is still in development, but already there are a variety of scenarios and training missions. The training is useful to give you an understanding of the less self-explanatory parts of the game, such as adjusting orbits. The scenarios put you into difficult situations and let you try and get out of them, and this is good practice for when you get to your own missions.

Eventually the game will contain a mode where you need to create your own space program. The costs of building rockets will presumably be offset by making money from missions, and this should make the game feel more directed. Crashing ships might be fun, but it does grow dull, and the real substance of the game is found in building efficient spacecraft and attempting to reach other planets.

Kerbal Space Program Oribit

Kerbal Space Program isn’t just for people who are interested in spacecraft. It’s a simulation, but it’s rarely restrictive and dull. You have the freedom to create your own designs, and when they fall apart you can laugh and try again. The game brings a sense of humor to the world of scientific simulation. Kerbal Space Program can be bought right now, and it’s recently been made available on Steam and Linux (I played the gabber on Ubuntu). There’s even a free demo. It’s still in development, but it’s already very playable, and I’d recommend that you give it a try.

10/10 Valves

voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was absolutely addicted to this game when I first picked it up, and honestly I can’t wait to kick my Space Engineers addiction and get back to my Kerbals!

I think it would be hard to describe the deep mechanics of this game without making it sound rather dry and educational, but as a huge fan of astronomy and the idea of space travel, I think this is a game everyone should give a go. Contrary to how some of the screen shots and discussion threads may appear, you don’t need an engineering degree to get something out of KSP. While the simulation aspect is very flushed out (and frequently being updated and fine tuned) there is enough arcade inspiration to allow for silly builds and brute force approaches to reach goals. At the same time however, those with a knack for math and engineering, your precision and dedication will be rewarded with epic adventures across the Kerbal Solar System.

Kerbal Space Program is a must buy in my book!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is truly amazing. As a kid, I've always dreamed of becoming a pilot, of a spaceplane or airplane, and this game lets me play with the realistic aerodynamics/physics of air/space travel, and it does it right.....oh, and it's still in beta! Except for minor glitches here and there, this game is perfect and VERY well made. It lets you build any rocket/spaceplane/airplane you want and fly it to distant planets/celestial bodies, land and return, all to complete missions to get more science, which you can use to unlock upgrades for your vehicles.

Right now, I've made the sexiest spaceplane you can imagine, which can get into orbit around Kerbin (home planet), transmit data and return back to base, in perfect shape. Kinda like an upgrade of the Space Shuttle (since it doesn't need external boosters to get into orbit).

See, this game is extremely realistic, so you get to learn a lot about the exact orbital mechanics NASA workers are required to know. I used to think getting into space was just firing a rocket straight up, but realistically, you need to have a high surface velocity so you can get into orbit, otherwise, you're wasting a ton of fuel on either flying far away from home or falling back to the earth due to gravity. There isn't zero gravity once you leave the atmosphere, that's only because there's just as much gravity the other way, due to your orbit in which you're constantly falling, but have a high enough velocity to generate an equal G-force the in the opposite direction. And if you want to go to the Mun (moon), you'll need to use your orbit to slingshot yourself to the place where you and the Mun moon will be at the same time, since you must take into account that the Mun also moves in an orbit.

I swear, you'll learn a TON about orbital physics, as well as you'll have a lot of fun building your spaceship however you want. And if it crashes to the ground, you must think about which part was misplaced to cause the crash, getting you in this trial and error loop until you FINALLY fix up the whole thing perfectly. Then you can think of its purpose-transport vessel, science lab, satellite launcher or a long distance traveler to a distant celestial body etc. etc. There's so much science to do, so many new ideas to think of and so much to learn from this game. Get the game and prepare to ignore every other game you have in your library because this game is out of this world! (literally)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Kerbal Space Program is a game about space. If you're interesting in nothing past CoD of Duty: Goats, then stop reading now.

---

KSP is complex and realistic (mostly) space travel with a twist: it's clear. So instead of being a sleep-deprivied, coffee-addict flight controller who needs to recite more instructions than should logically be in existance, you are simply given the controls the fly the rocket - WASD, camera, throttle, and so on. There is no clutter.

KSP has a lot of freedom in what to do in it. Recently, the Campaign mode was introduced, which tasks you with balancing the reputation, budget, and science of the Kerbal Space Program whilst pushing further and further and building up to greater things. If you prefer the simpler things, there is also the Science mode, in which the only restriction is what parts you have to unlock, or the Sandbox, where everything is given on no limitations.

The main protagonists in the game are the Kerbals. Assuming you are fine with the prospect of cartoonish, green panicking-astronauts screaming as your rocket flies into mountains at Mach 5, KSP's light-hearted side appeals to everyone. Your little kerbals will grin like children at a Minecraft Convention as they gracefully land on the Mun, or enjoy the views of a gas giant and it's moons. Upon landing, you can plop down a flag and claim this ball of regolith for you: because in KSP, the solar system is yours.

KSP has many oppertunities. You may endeavour on projects from a reusable shuttle, to space station, to moon base. If you have the time and ideas to make something, possibilities await. Assisting this is the diversity of the modding community: on a parallel to Minecraft's, the modding community is very large and it should even be noted that many ideas have been incorporated - like the C7 Aerospace parts, whose creator was hired for the staff to help develop them, and the soon-to-be multiplayer function: something that was off-limits for the staff before, until it was proven by a modification that multiplayer and KSP can indeed go together.

The Official KSP forums have areas for user built craft and items, help and assistance, and pictures and discussion. It's worth a visit if you have any questions, need a helping hand, or simply wish to browse the latest craft available.

If you're interested by KSP at this point, don't hesitate to consider buying. It's an excellent game and will continue to improve - because it's still in development.

But on the other side, even without Workshop, getting mods and setting them off in your game is not problematic at all. Regards for Squad, hopefully they will not stop improving KSP.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

KSP is without doubt the most fun I have ever had failing, and failing over and over again, because when you finally get that first craft into orbit it is the most amazing feeling of accomplishment I have ever experienced from a game. If you have ANY interest at all in space exploration, rocket science, orbital mechanics, little green men, or BLOODY BIG EXPLOSIONS, then THIS is the game for you.

Though it is as yet incomplete, each and every update has brought something new to re-invigorate the game. The modding community and community in general surrounding this game is just fantastic, with so much going on all the time that you will always have something to do. And now that the career mode is in the game, each update makes things more interesting and makes setting and acheiving goals that much more satisfying.

Once again, if space flight and planetary exploration interest you, this is your game. If managing a complex space program is your idea of fun I am sure this will soon be your game, though with mods it can be your game right now. The way Squad is supporting modding and making updates means that this game can be just about anything you want from a game if your interested in Space simulations and fun.

And of course you can't beat the explosions when it all goes just that little bit wrong :D

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Launch a thriving campaign of atrocities as your dubiously-engineered deathtraps murder thousands upon thousands of Vietnamese astronauts!

Spend hours making steady progress towards an enduring anxiety disorder as you thrust in the general direction of your docking target, only to see it pass by you like your partner en route to a more interesting, virile, darker man.

Catalogue your personal decay into an agoraphobic disaster as your hundreds of failed missions expose you to the unfathomable scale of our galaxy. After coming to terms with the violent inhospitability of our entire ♥♥♥♥ing universe, take refuge in the fact that you, by a vast margin, consist of empty space, and the death which rapidly approaches you will go unnoticed by those mindless spheres that patrol the deep void.

10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I absolutely LOVE this game.  I definitely recommend it if you love space/space exploration as much as I do.  The physics aren't exactly 'real world' but for a simulator they are phenomenal.  If you're a trial and error kind of person, you'll enjoy it.  If you're a patient person, you'll enjoy it.  If you're a person able to learn things, you'll enjoy it.

There really aren't any full tutorials in game, but the kerbal wiki is rich with material.  It's still early access, but for an early access game it's definitely blown me away.  You start off at a space center on an earth-like planet 'Kerbin.'  You can then either build a rocket from scratch or load a pre-made one; I recommend the latter just to get a feel for the game.  Once you know what you're doing, you can pretty much decide what you're doing from there.

They've added a career mode recently, and I think it holds some promise.  So far you perform launches with a limited amount of parts for your rockets and conduct experiments at different altitudes and locations.  Those experiments will get you 'science points' which are spent to research a new technology on a tech-tree.  The said techonology will unlock more parts for your ship to further your launches which in turn further your experiments.  More points, more parts, more research.  It goes on.  Career mode is still in development so I expect a lot more from it in the future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A review that should have come a long long time ago.  What can I say about Kerbal Space Program other than buy it.   Buy a copy for yourself, buy copies for your family memebers, and buy copies as gifts for your friends.

Hands down the best money on entertainment I have ever spent.  I've spent more hours than I care to admit to playing this gem of a game and in addition to the sheer joy and feelings of accomplishment this game gives its users you will also find yourself learning a ton about orbital mechanics in a fun and exciting way.

That feeling of accomplishment is so core to the Kerbal Space Program experience.  I can't think of a single KSP player who doesn't have a first docking story or loads of screenshots/videos from their first landing on another planet.  The list is endless with this game.

Another great part of the KSP experience is the community here and on the main forums.  The mod community is large and very active.  Mods for this title will blow you away!!!  So much so that some mods were swallowed up by the developers and the mod developers now work along side Squad.

If you have not yet bought this game I invite you to download the demo here on Steam or from www.KerbalSpaceProgram.com  After downloading the demo hit Youtube and grab some popcorn for the hours upon hours of tutorials and general fun surrounding this game.  If your anything like me it won't take but 5 minutes in the demo before you instantly see the value of this game.

Click buy!!!  You will not regret your purchase!!!!

reviewText: Tip for Kerbal Space Program players: Hitting Alt+F4 does not bring Bob Kerman back from playing with his jetpack on the moon, flying 40+ m/s into the side of a crater. Hitting Alt+F4 does also not fill Jedebiah Kerman with EVA propellant so he can get back to his orbiting space ship. Hitting Alt+F4 also does not reverse the 40 minutes you spent getting to Duna, only to realize you forgot Newke Kerman. Hitting Alt+F4 does not revive your sanity after going back to your vehicle assembly, putting Newke Kerman in your pod, flying back to Duna, and not having enough fuel to slow yourself down, going 30 m/s over the limit, and killing Newke Kerman. Hitting Alt+F4 also does not make you feel less stupid about getting rid of your landing rockets, and putting on four parachutes because you realized that Duna has an atmosphere. Hitting Alt+F4 saves you from embarrassment when you pull up your steam overlay, and realize you messed up your amazing trajectory to Minmus by hitting the Shift key to pull up the Steam overlay, only to do it again and tell your friend about how you're stressed and angry because you just messed up your path to Minmus, only to be cut short because you made yourself an escape trajectory out of Kerbin because once again, you hit Shift.

reviewText:
This game is fantastic.

It makes me loathe my own stupidity by just how much I suck when playing it though. For me it's more like Kerbal Explosion Program.

Regardless, there's nothing else like it and the attention to both detail and believable physics is fantastic. Plus the Kerbals are great. Their silly facial expressions when faced with the certain doom of being in one of my contraptions adds a whimsical side to an otherwise straight forward sim game.

Anyone who loves NASA or SpaceX, anyone with a passion for all things science, anyone who likes to stir in a bit of learning with their game playing, this game is likely for you. I highly recommend it to just about anyone. As I said earlier, there is simply nothing else like this game and that alone makes it worth a look.

Cheers! :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is easily one of the best indie games you can get your filthy moondust covered hands on.

Although the learning curve in the beginning is pretty steep for someone who isn't aware of basic orbital physics or is on par with the navball or rocket construction, it's nothing a couple of videos from Scott Manley (or Robbaz if you intend to just make space a circus) can't fix. If you however know what you are doing and/or have been following someone who knows what they're doing you should have no problem at all getting into this game.

It features many planets, their moons and in the future even an asteroid belt you'll be able to interact with all from the comfort of your own room/NASA mission control centre.

You can build everything from rockets, space planes, landers, probes and god knows what.
The game also features modding support and mods for the game can be found on the KSP site. Mods can add everything from boat parts, weapons, tools for making robots and mechs, new parts to add to the already pretty big library of parts and even customized planets.

The game is however somewhat unstable and building large stations etc can often cause horrible lag on all but the beefiest computers, it is however only a problem when you build VERY large stuff and once the game is finished the optimization will no doubt be better than it currently is.

I truly recommend this game to any and all of you! There is something for pretty much everyone in this game, if there isn't then mods have probably added it.
If your PC can run this game, I see no reason for you not buying it. Trust me the game is worth every penny but if it's on a sale you pretty much have to buy it. Your life is not complete without this game. Get it now. Seriously.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Definitely my most favourite game of this 2013, and it's not even finished yet!

The idea is to make spacecraft to explore the solar system. Sounds simple, right?

There are two basic game modes, Career and Sandbox. In sandbox mode you get all the pieces to play with, and can design anything you can conceive with the parts available to take you as far as you like. This is how I started playing the game and it provided hours of entertainment and explosions, but it does rely to an extent on setting your own goals. See if you can get to the Mun. Then Minmus. Land on each one. Get to other planets. Make a space station. It goes on!

Career mode was recently introduced and definitely simplifies the learning curve a lot, limiting your starting builds and unlocking parts through performing science, and adds a lot of value to the experience, as well as adding a purpose for some of the parts that seem to be pointless in sandbox mode.

Finally, the modding community is extremely active for this game with mods to add mineable resources, expand part lists, and adding new methods of travelling (warp anyone?), and even a multiplayer mod still in its infancy.

Without a doubt the best value for money in terms of time played for me.

Early Access Review

Bloody great game!

at the beginning it seems inceredible hard to to even do something as simple as bringing a capsule into orbit or performing the docking of two vessels (Youtube helps).

once u understand the simple orbital mechanics it starts getting really cool.

u ever wanted to have ur own MÜNBASE? just build it.

u ever wanted to do research on other planets? just get there.

its all about orbital logistics and proper kerbal engineering.
fiddeling rockets for a specialzed task together and optimizing them is a lot of fun.
and when it works u really get the feeling u achieved something.


and there is a damn crapton of really good mods (Kerbal Spaceport is the official Mod Site).
from simple part packs, over complete solar system rescaling to the real size of our solar system, over warpdrive plugins to resource harvesting mods .
building a münbase to harvest fuel to refill ur vessel which is supposed to reach the outer planets?
get the mod and do it.

(all mods are easy to install and remove)

but enough about the mods even the normal game got a lot of really cool things to discover.

even tho that the game has by now ONLY" the half of the promised features (things like the finised career mode or multi player)
date:
the damn game still better than quite some AAA titles which charge u 50 bucks and hand u a unfinished and unplayble game

if u thinking about getting ur hands on this game ...... DO IT !"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you're thinking about buying this game if you have not purchased it yet... Let me give you a few reasons why it is worth getting.

Positive

• Extremely fun
• Gather more information about aircrafts/rockets
• Watching the faces at the bottom right = gg wp
• Freebuilding any aircraft/rocket to go any planet or maybe just to freeroam in space
• Mods
• Not many bugs

Negative

• Can be difficult to learn
• Can be very time consuming
• Does take a while to get science points which is used to unlock parts for rockets/aircrafts

Overall Reason

Okay so there isn't so much to add to the lists above but what I can say is that this game is absolutely beautiful to play. It feels amazing when you first ever orbit the kerbal earth or when you first ever land on the moon using the rocket/aircraft you have created. You can also be very creative with everything you make, who knows? you could make a flying UFO or maybe a really tiny rocket which could possible reach the 'mun'.

WORTH THE BUY :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is worth the money two times over.
The best part about it is the community, you can download countless modifications.
If you don't want to use mods, than vanilla is extremely fun as well, you manage your own space program,
Soon even the tinest thing matters, if its money, or even reputation!
This is a fantastic game, You get fear when a mission goes wrong, and you immedietally try to stop and do whatever you can to ensure the safety of your kerbals! You feel accomplished when you take those first steps on the moon, and you see your kerbals smile on re-entry, knowing that they are heroes to all of kerbal-kind. You feel a sense of continuaty when your space ship doesn't go as planned, and you rush to find what the problem is.
You start to get addicted, and before you know it, you're writing a 10/10 review on this piece of art.

This, my friends, is a piece of what gaming always wanted to be. A fantasy world, truely in your mind, where you can dream up what you want, when you want, and how you want it. Think Minecraft in space, where you have to make the complex calculations to get to Duna, the kerbin equvilant of Mars.

Now, the thing is, all of this is about x8 easier than what it is in real life.
Once you figure out physics and the complex mojo that really makes NASA's scientists, well, NASA's scientists, you start speaking it aswell, you start reading on and on with the changelogs, and before you know it, It's halloween and you're dressing up as a Kerbal.

This is what I see in this game, a fantastic piece of gaming history that should be carefully monitered, and is one of those games you might find bad, then you play the game. This is the game you want to throw $ at so that it lives.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You like space, but you want to play a game where thrust, fuel efficiency and orbital mechanics actually matter? Even if you are not familiar with these, you will learn. After learning how to make a proper rocket, you'll learn getting to the moon is not just burning toward it. You'll learn travelling to other planets is not as hard as they are far away from you. You'll learn timing saves fuel. You'll learn to use the gravity of planets to go farther. And then you'll realize this is how rocket scientists are actually thinking when designing real-life rockets. You'll watch movies about space and cringe at their representation of orbital maneuvers. You'll understand why Apollo missions were using docking. You'll know why Mars missions take years. And so on.

But at the beginning, you will often crash your rocket into the ground.

First let me state that I am usually one of the last to promote crowd sourcing" or "early access" schemes as they offer little to no consumer protection.



Having said that however I came across a little demo on Steam that impressed me greatly.  The title of this little gem is Kerbal Space Program ( no I have no idea wtf a Kerbal is):

https://kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php

I was bored at the time so I figured wth and downloaded the demo

https://kerbalspaceprogram.com/demo.php



54 hours played later(according to Steam)it took me 5 hrs (played) just to reach a stable orbit and once I discovered the joys of calculating/plotting planetary intercepts I was hooked.(side note: as it has a pretty healthy mod community if one finds orbital transfers

votesHelpful: or piloting in general un-fun; there are various auto pilot mods to take care of some or all of the "fiddly bits" for you.  There is no "official" auto pilot as yet
votesTotal:
that is planed further down the road.

a couple of screenshots of my first Mun (yes Mun not Moon)Landing in the demo...well landing is such a subjective word

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=169992980

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=169992928
The game is currently in alpha testing; Uses the Unity game engine; currently has only sandbox mode available(although the next update is going to start implementing career mode elements); has a fairly healthy mod community; Early access if you choose to do it is $23 US. It is single player.  Worked with Windows/MAC/LINUX

The demo has 1 planet and 1 moon

the full game has an entire solar system loosely based on ours



The premise behind the game is design/build/launch rockets
votesFunny: landers
commentsCount: rovers
column16: space planes
column17: space stations
column18:
and scientific probes while not blowing S*** up.  The freedom of the design elements of the game is pretty impressive in itself (at least to me) I spend way too much time in the VAB(Vehicle Assembly Building) Again referencing the community if you find this part tedious..yup ready made designs are there for the breaking.  Approved mods can be found in the spaceport site.

http://kerbalspaceport.com/





Of course like any alpha there are "issues"  the biggest to my mind is the limitation the engine introduces.  At some point one learns that performance drops off significantly with increasing part counts.  As stated earlier it uses the Unity game engine an independent community designed engine.  This means unlike a lot of games KSP relies more on CPU than GPU it also can run on only 1 processor core.  These means past a certain point increasing performance requires Overclocking your rig or using less parts in your designs. 300-600 parts tends to be the avg big drop-off range.  The issue is significant enough there is even a cpu performance database

http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/42877-CPU-Performance-Database?highlight=database

I've found  KSP to be an extremely addicting little game(452 hrs played according to Steam) so if one is willing to look past it's rough spots (it is alpha after all) it can be incredibly enjoyable"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I think i'll begin this review of Kerbal Space Program with a few stories of things I have done in the game.  First is the quest I had to assemble a modular outpost on the Mun.  Complete with living quarters a solar array/battery bank.  It also had O2 and CO2 storage and a converter.  Finally I added the Kethane(Methane) drilling rig and a plant to convert it to usable rocket fuel.   Next up was the journey to research science from near sun.  I flew a space probe to various altitudes near the sun.  Starting at 1 million km, next 100km, and finally 10,000m.  The last altitude I discovered a fun glitch in the game where the suns gravity accelerated my probe to near the speed of light and it shortly disintegrated.

At its core Kerbal Space Program (KSP) is a physics simulation of a solar system and the player is given pieces to make rockets and explore the stars.  Of course there is sandbox mode where all parts are available and the player doesn't have to worry about money or unlocking more advanced parts.  In sandbox the only objective are ones the player must create.  But the real fun starts in career mode that was recently updated to give the player contracts to give them various objectives.  Also part of career mode is the need to balance money and reputation.  The way to unlock better and more advanced parts in career is by performing science.

Of course you might be leary of KSP being early access, but I will say that in terms of content the game is amazing.  I'd buy it in its current state ten times over.  However if you're still not satisfied one of the games biggest strengths is the dedicated modding community.  Want to only focus on building ships and let the autopilot launch and land your crafts.  Theres a mod for that.  Want to add even more rocket parts, the ability to build and connect space crafts.  Theres a mod for that.  Want to make the game super realistic and add O2, CO2, and a realistic atmosphere where your ship can and will burn up during re-entry.  Or you could add Kethane, the games equivalent to Methane, that you can mine and make rocket fuel on distant planets.  Well you see where this is going :)

Finally my criticisms.  The biggest one that I hope gets worked on by the devs is optimization.  The physics engine only utilizes a single core of your CPU.  This is frustrating because I have an AMD CPU and not only does it struggle with single core vs Intel but the game doesn't take advantage of my multi core CPU.  Remember that sweet moon station I mentioned, well it got too big and the game ran at ~11 FPS near my station.  Secondly if you install a bunch of mods the games takes a while to load.

Overall if you love Lego and space exploration KSP is an amazing game.

reviewText: “Look again at that dot. That's here. That's home. That's us. On it everyone you love, everyone you know, everyone you ever heard of, every human being who ever was, lived out their lives. The aggregate of our joy and suffering, thousands of confident religions, ideologies, and economic doctrines, every hunter and forager, every hero and coward, every creator and destroyer of civilization, every king and peasant, every young couple in love, every mother and father, hopeful child, inventor and explorer, every teacher of morals, every corrupt politician, every superstar
recommended:
every saint and sinner in the history of our species lived there-on a mote of dust suspended in a sunbeam.

The Earth is a very small stage in a vast cosmic arena. Think of the endless cruelties visited by the inhabitants of one corner of this pixel on the scarcely distinguishable inhabitants of some other corner, how frequent their misunderstandings, how eager they are to kill one another, how fervent their hatreds. Think of the rivers of blood spilled by all those generals and emperors so that, in glory and triumph, they could become the momentary masters of a fraction of a dot.

Our posturings, our imagined self-importance, the delusion that we have some privileged position in the Universe, are challenged by this point of pale light. Our planet is a lonely speck in the great enveloping cosmic dark. In our obscurity, in all this vastness, there is no hint that help will come from elsewhere to save us from ourselves.

The Earth is the only world known so far to harbor life. There is nowhere else, at least in the near future, to which our species could migrate. Visit, yes. Settle, not yet. Like it or not, for the moment the Earth is where we make our stand.

It has been said that astronomy is a humbling and character-building experience. There is perhaps no better demonstration of the folly of human conceits than this distant image of our tiny world. To me, it underscores our responsibility to deal more kindly with one another, and to preserve and cherish the pale blue dot, the only home we've ever known.”


- Carl Sagan
