reviewText:
Early Access Review

I never knew flying out into space in a cardboard box could be so tranquil and beautiful.

This is probably my favorite game on Steam; I have had it for a little while now (since about v0.14).  I have put many hours into KSP and yet I still don't know how to describe the character and depth this game has to offer.  It is perfectly situated in that place where silliness and fiction meet complex science and math to form a uniquely fantastic game.  The creative graphics, gameplay and interface are very well in tune with each other and work in tandem quite effectively.

The community add-ons greatly enhance the experience and are a must-have for those who like to spice up their missions.  The mod base is so extensive, you can incorporate everything from epic science modules and probe paraphernalia to loads of different rocket engines, solar panels, and landing gear.

Most importantly however, you can in fact launch a kerbal into orbit, deorbit him, and watch him burn up in the atmosphere until he hits the ground at 120 meters per second.  Of course, if he lands head-first, it is interesting to watch as his indestructible helmet propels him several hundred meters back into the air.

Overall, I believe that KSP is for gamers of all types and can be suited very easily to the user.  I can live with the cons because they're all either bound to be fixed or don't even matter anyways.  I always keep coming back for more kerbal adventures.

Solid 100/10 because it makes me chuckle

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I originally played this game about 2 years ago and absolutely loved it. Tho, at the time, resources (from my wallet) were low. Soooo... I went the underground route and got the game from other means. I loved it so much and played for the longest time. 300 plus hours on this game. I recently uncovered the game again and fell inlove once again, the new updates were amazing, tho at this time my funds were still low. But finally, I was able to work up enough means to get quite a few games, KSP at the top of the list. The game is amazing, I'll list my Pro's and Con's below (cons being low)

Pros:
Vast universe with amazing details.
Great physics
Updates aren't cheesy!
Funny little green guys
So much to do, new things to craft
Extremely addictive

Cons:
No multiplayer (yet)
Not enough green guys
For some reason when you multiply speed whilst lifting, u go boom.

All in all, this game is amazing, and you should so totally get it

9.9/10

reviewText:
I've been waiting patiently before reviewing this game and finally they released it so i can post my thoughts about it.

The idea behind this game is amazing - you get to explore a solar system, build various rockets, pretend to be an engineer, a pilot or an explorer. They've managed to allow as much creativity as it actually possible at this current development level for simulation/strategy game.

HOWEVER (it is a big however, i know) before you can actually enjoy anything like building a satellite to orbit around some distant planet, or a two way mission to the Mun - you will either have to learn hours and hours, and hours, and hours, even more hours of youtube tutorials or... cheat.

When it comes to tutorials and explaining how things work in the game we made" the developers failed so miserably
recommended: that you actually have to wonder which audience they intended this game for?\n\nTelling a new player to try and land a vehicle near space center - is not a tutorial. Forgetting to mention recently added features like heating and cooling
hoursPlayed: so they would inevitably burn in the atmosphere is a shocking oversight. Not mentioning how to save up fuel when launching vessels
voteText: changing orbits or de-orbiting is just lousy.\n\nBottom line is - there is no comprehensive tutorial in this game whatsoever
helpfulPercent: no learning curve
votesHelpful: no actually useful in game tips
votesTotal: tooltips or explanations on anything. Period.\n\nSo before you actually can enjoy this game in its fullest (repetitively launching badly designed pieces of crap is just a part of it) - you will have to spend hours learning how the hell you can launch a vessel properly
votesFunny: save fuel
commentsCount: dock
column16: transfer to another object
column17: land
column18: land in different atmosphere
column19: land without an atmosphere
column20: take off
column21: etc. etc. etc.\n\nI was expecting them to completely revamp the tutorials and the learning curve - they did not. Because of that i was prepared to thumb it down but i could not. Even though developers clearly do not care about players actually getting into their game and enjoying it without wasting a lot of time - modders do care. There are mods that allow cheating
column22: better parts and complete designs which reduce the difficulty curve significantly. There are also plenty of videos (i recommend Scott Manley) which explain various game aspects in details and manage to be both interesting and educational at the same time.\n\nSo yeah... while i am very disappointed in developers
column23: the community and modders made this game better
column24: good enough to recommend it."

Early Access Review

Kerbal Space Program is a great game which I first played with my friend who loves space simulators. After a few hours we quickly fell in love with getting rockets lost in space, terrible landings and killing hundreds of kerbals. The entire day and night was lost in this immersive game.

The game has since been released on steam (obviously) and we have continued to enjoy hour after hour exploring the solar system. With many successful and failed missions, I have slowly become a better pilot, whilst still enjoying every hour playing the game.

I would strongly recommend Kerbal Space Program for anyone, regarless of your intrest in space simulation games. With many updates adding astounding new features, you will fall in love with the many apsects of space travel.

Start small and build your way up.

From a single-engine, one-manned ship that barely makes it above the atmosphere, to a multi-staged Mun-lander capable of returning your crew alive and in tact. This game is worth every penny as well as every minute you'll spend learning rocket science*.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is one of the best games I have ever played.  It is an indie game and not yet in full release, but the developers are highly communicative with the community and regular updates are released almost always adding major features or bug fixes.  The modding community is extremely dedicated and the developers are highly supportive of it to the point where they have hired several of the best modders straight from the community.

I've put over 250 hours into this game since its been on Steam, but that doesn't count the hundreds of hours I put in before it was on Steam.

The game is extremely worth it and has an extremely bright future ahead of it.  There is no clear objective system at the moment though, which has turned some people off the game.  I don't believe its coming in the next update but their main priority is currently fleshing out the 'career' mode (as opposed to the sandbox mode that most people play) where there will be objectives, funding, and research.  Research has already been added but it needs some major fixing, which is actually their expressed priority for the coming update.

TLDR; The game is very much worth it, if you're interested in spacetravel at all go for it.  The satisfaction of landing on the Mun (Kerbal equivalent of the Moon) on your own for the first time more than makes it worth the cost, not to mention the hundreds of other things there are for you to do.

Oh, and if you're still on the fence there is a free demo for you to try.  It only includes a fraction of the parts and celestial bodies that are available in the full version and does not include the career mode, but it gives you a good idea of what the full game is like.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The only game I have ever played that, when successfully building and launching a rocket to then deploy a lander on the moon followed by an elaborate docking process once back in space led to an ambitious return to the home planet without killing any of my crewmen, gave me a TRUE sense of personal accomplishment that has rivalled real-life accomplishments.

That may sound lame to some of you who are not hardcore about gaming, while it may sound strange to you hardcore gamers who find accomplishment in successes from other games. I tell you this being a 29-year old gamer veteran of 25 long years (Tandy PC jr., TI Home Computer, Amiga, Commodore 64, and Atari 2600 for starters) who has seen many games come and go. I'm sure that Kerbal may not be a true pioneer of the sandbox sim, yet I have never met a game that has kept me riveted to my PC for as long as this one.

Kerbal can create an experience never lived for most of you who grew up wanting either to be an astronaut or a rocket scientist (or both!) and presents it in a fashion that is otherwise unattainable in any other media form. The creation process can be frustrating and unforgiving, between the thrust/mass/control coefficients and the staging management ensuring your success/demise right at the paddock, yet always gives a personal sense of enjoyment when your self-concocted combination of (loosely) held together parts engineered for home plumbing/rocketry when it finally does work out and you break that atmospheric threshold between Kerbin and space.

The graphics are solid; with a moderate gaming laptop or mediocre desktop PC, this game can still shine. The only time I have run into issues with my Ivy Bridge i7 with 670MX GPU laptop running all features @1080p is when I created a six-part space station with lighting fixtures in low orbit (125 km). This causes some choppy camera effects which can easily be resolved with lowering res or AA.

The physics are unmatched; the way each rocket adds mass with thrust, providing an unnerving sense of realism to having too much or not enough on either of these factors. This is a mechanism that other space games should take note of.

The story is unnecessary and therefore (so far) omitted. This is an exploration game with no prome directive. If Squad does finalize the game and provide any type of a campaign, it will only be a plus on an already incredible design.

The gameplay is certainly something special; you build, launch, stage, deploy, land, and dock to your heart's content! There are also some other great features Squad has done with the R&D facility and science points (it provides a heck of a challenge starting with very little to promote a scientific approach to your exploration and desire for more research). The full solar system exploration will provide countless hours of efforts to send unmanned satellites to the farthest reaches, and perhaps even manned vessels of you are REALLY amibitious.

Overall this game, as it stands, is a 10/10 even though there is still so much left for it to improve on but the foundation of what is the single greatest Early Access Game released on Steam certainly surpasses the expectations I could have ever had of it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

PROS:
Modding support.
The developers encourage modding and the modding community for this game is pretty big. While modding extends a game's life and increases enjoyment you can easily have fun with the stock unmodified game. I would reccomend Engineer, MechJeb and Kerbal Attachment System to start.

Easy to start.
You don't need to know a thing about real world rocketry to play this. There are in-game tutorials for most of the game aspects and the community has written out details about the advanced stuff.

(Mostly) Friendly community.
While every community has its share of not nice" people
date:
KSP has an invested fan base who will help and support each other. Don't know about a certain thing in the game? You won't be ridiculed for not knowing.

Quicksaving and reverting are enabled.
Afraid to take some of the Kerbal crew you have grown attached to on a dangerous mission? Have no fear
recommended:
saves are here! F5 quicksaves the game while F9 reloads the quicksave. Need to take a few tries before you successfully do a powered landing? Just quicksave. Crash terribly before you had the chance to save? Revert to the launchpad. For people who don't like to quicksave it is 100% optional and there are even no in-game checkpoints.

Not stuck to one flight.
Don't feel like time accelerating while waiting for your deep space probe's course correction? No problem! Just switch to another ship
hoursPlayed:
your probe will still make progress. A mod called "Kerbal Alarm Clock" is great for letting you know when your ships need to be paid attention to.

NASA street cred.
For KSP's 23.5 update they actually worked with NASA to add things to the game. While the game isn't 100% realistic you can tell that the developers are balancing realism with unrealistic things.

Demo available.
More games should come with a "try before you buy" feature and demos are a great way of giving that. If you are really unsure about if the game is for you
voteText:
get the demo.

Rewarding gameplay.
Knowing the ship you created landed on the Mun
helpfulPercent: or even made it into Kerbin orbit
votesHelpful:
is a great feeling. Being able to bring your crew home safely is also great. I remember my first attempt at a crewed landing on the Mun. I didn't have enough fuel to land on the Mun so I sent an unmanned ship to refuel it using the KAS mod. After refueling I landed on the Mun after several tries. I planted my flag and launched back into orbit only to realize that I didn't have enough fuel to get back so I rendezvoused with the refueling vessel. When I finally made it back to Kerbin and splash downed in the ocean it was a great feeling.


CONS:
Not everyone can pick up and play.
Some people will not be able to figure out the game and will think it is too complicated. There is online material to help with understanding the game but that might not be enough.

==
I have spent more time on this game than any other game. I enjoy it that much. More than half my time is spent designing vessels but I am learning more and more. Often I will not have played the game for a few days when I feel it pulling me back in. I definitely recommend this game."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Best Game Ever!.. In my opinion anyway ;)

If you have a background of interest in sandbox and/or simulator games you're sure to get your money's worth of enjoyment out of Kerbal Space Program.

The game is renowned for having a truly Everest like learning curve. So if you're a type to be frustrated when things don't work first time round beware.

However, at this point the game has a nice set of tutorials to get you going on the basics and some clearly thought out scenarios which you can use to drop you in situations to practice most other things (without going to the trouble of getting those pesky rockets off the launch pad).

I have found the game to be relatively low on bugs at this point (although rockets do have a tendency to fall apart on the launch pad sometimes). But as the game is still early access it's safe to assume these will be fixed with time.

Overall Kerbal is a Great Game. Lots of depth for those willing to put in the time and the promise of comical failures and explosions for all!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The only game I have ever played that, when successfully building and launching a rocket to then deploy a lander on the moon followed by an elaborate docking process once back in space led to an ambitious return to the home planet without killing any of my crewmen, gave me a TRUE sense of personal accomplishment that has rivalled real-life accomplishments.

That may sound lame to some of you who are not hardcore about gaming, while it may sound strange to you hardcore gamers who find accomplishment in successes from other games. I tell you this being a 29-year old gamer veteran of 25 long years (Tandy PC jr., TI Home Computer, Amiga, Commodore 64, and Atari 2600 for starters) who has seen many games come and go. I'm sure that Kerbal may not be a true pioneer of the sandbox sim, yet I have never met a game that has kept me riveted to my PC for as long as this one.

Kerbal can create an experience never lived for most of you who grew up wanting either to be an astronaut or a rocket scientist (or both!) and presents it in a fashion that is otherwise unattainable in any other media form. The creation process can be frustrating and unforgiving, between the thrust/mass/control coefficients and the staging management ensuring your success/demise right at the paddock, yet always gives a personal sense of enjoyment when your self-concocted combination of (loosely) held together parts engineered for home plumbing/rocketry when it finally does work out and you break that atmospheric threshold between Kerbin and space.

The graphics are solid; with a moderate gaming laptop or mediocre desktop PC, this game can still shine. The only time I have run into issues with my Ivy Bridge i7 with 670MX GPU laptop running all features @1080p is when I created a six-part space station with lighting fixtures in low orbit (125 km). This causes some choppy camera effects which can easily be resolved with lowering res or AA.

The physics are unmatched; the way each rocket adds mass with thrust, providing an unnerving sense of realism to having too much or not enough on either of these factors. This is a mechanism that other space games should take note of.

The story is unnecessary and therefore (so far) omitted. This is an exploration game with no prome directive. If Squad does finalize the game and provide any type of a campaign, it will only be a plus on an already incredible design.

The gameplay is certainly something special; you build, launch, stage, deploy, land, and dock to your heart's content! There are also some other great features Squad has done with the R&D facility and science points (it provides a heck of a challenge starting with very little to promote a scientific approach to your exploration and desire for more research). The full solar system exploration will provide countless hours of efforts to send unmanned satellites to the farthest reaches, and perhaps even manned vessels of you are REALLY amibitious.

Overall this game, as it stands, is a 10/10 even though there is still so much left for it to improve on but the foundation of what is the single greatest Early Access Game released on Steam certainly surpasses the expectations I could have ever had of it.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is my favorite  steam game that I own. It is really cool designing your own Rockets and Planes, flying to other planets, docking on your space station and adding new scientific tools or even simply going around the moon on a rover. I would definitely recommend this game as it combines science with fun. This game is extremely realistic in almost all the areas including orbit mechanics and other areas like aerodynamic drag. Some parts are unrealistic like there is no re-entry heat in the regular game but if you go to KerbalSpacePort.com which is created by Kerbal Space Program, you can get many mods which add alot to the game. If you wanted to simulate re-entry, get the deadly re-entry mod and be sure to put Heat Shields on your space ship. If you want more plane parts, get B9 Aerospace. For more rocket parts, I recommend KW Rocketry. You can find a mod for almost everything from new parts to new things you can do like creating a map of the planets with a satellite and then using it to find a cool place to land. This game gets a 5/5 rating from me and since it is only in Beta, I expect more to come since already, this looks like an official game. ~Mountain Lion~

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is by far one of the best games I've ever played. It kind of reminds me what Spore could have been!

You can really build your rockets from scratch and they will (or will not) fly if the model is nice. It's not a hard game, have very good tutorials and let you be free to reach whatever planets you want!

Every planet is different and have stunning visuals, different gravity levels and atmospheres. You can explore all planets using rovers, spacecrafts and rockets made by your own hands! It's really cool and rewarding to make your first Mun" landing or to orbit a far away planet.

Sometimes you'll lose Kerbals to terrible accidents or to the lack of fuel or even to bad planned landings and so far
date: my mission is to rescue them and bring them back home! :D"
